Brave Bird hits Fighting-resistant foes such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Galarian Zapdos for good damage. Both of these moves can be very hard to switch into, as even physically defensive walls like Hippowdon, Clefable, and Skarmory get 2HKOed. Blaze Kick is mainly used to hit Aegislash, which otherwise completely walls Galarian Zapdos. Stomping Tantrum can be used as a more powerful alternative to hit both Aegislash and Heatran super effectively, but it risks being Choice-locked against Skarmory and Celesteela. U-turn lets Galarian Zapdos pivot against checks such as Slowbro and Galarian Corsola and bring in a teammate to deal with them. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows Galarian Zapdos to outspeed threats like Hydreigon, Kyurem, Mimikyu, and Tapu Lele.

Landorus-T is an invaluable teammate, as it switches into Electric-type attacks from foes like Zeraora and Tapu Koko, provides Stealth Rock, Knock Off, and U-turn support, and can revenge kill foes like Dragapult and Spectrier with Choice Scarf. Stealth Rock is especially useful to wear down foes and give Galarian Zapdos opportunities to gain Defiant boosts because of Defog. In return, Galarian Zapdos can pressure walls that give Landorus-T trouble such as Celesteela, Galarian Weezing, and Swampert, as well as Defoggers like Corviknight and Mandibuzz thanks to Defiant. Celesteela or Corviknight can be used to provide a switch-in against Psychic-, Ice-, and Fairy-type attacks from foes like Latias, Kyurem, and Alolan Ninetales. Skarmory can also be used as an excellent physically defensive wall, shutting down threatening physical attackers such as Weavile, Mamoswine, and Urshifu-R more easily. In addition, it provides Spikes support, making Galarian Zapdos more difficult to switch into. Mantine provides a useful Water immunity, handling threats that can overpower Galarian Zapdos like Barraskewda and Kingdra. Thundurus-T is also a useful way to deal with Water teams, as it can defeat the entirety of it with Thunderbolt + Grass Knot while being hard to stop after a Nasty Plot and Agility boost. Galarian Moltres is a great tool against Psychic, Ghost, and Poison teams, notably dealing with answers to Galarian Zapdos such as Slowbro, Galarian Corsola, and Galarian Weezing. Tornadus-T is a great offensive pivot that can bring in Galarian Zapdos safely with U-turn while helping against types like Psychic and Ghost thanks to Knock Off.

sets.name: Choice Band (Fighting)
sets.description:
Brave Bird acts as Galarian Zapdos's main STAB move, dealing massive damage to any Pokemon not resisting it, OHKOing Pokemon such as Amoonguss, Buzzwole, and Choice Specs Tapu Lele and 2HKOing Pokemon like Clefable and Toxapex after Stealth Rock damage. STAB Close Combat complements Brave Bird nicely, helping it hit Rock- and Steel-type Pokemon like Celesteela, Jirachi, and Tyranitar. Thunderous Kick can be used over Close Combat to avoid Defense drops and deal with physical walls like Klefki and Mandibuzz a bit better. U-turn helps Galarian Zapdos pivot out of tough matchups or pick off weakened Pokemon while maintaining momentum alongside Pokemon like Volt Switch Cobalion and Flip Turn Keldeo. Blaze Kick acts as coverage to hit Pokemon like Aegislash and Zapdos better. Defiant is a great ability that allows it to punish Intimidate and Defog users such as Landorus-T and Galarian Weezing, respectively. Maximum Speed investment along with a Jolly nature helps Galarian Zapdos outspeed threats such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele, non-Choice Scarf Urshifu-R, and Mimikyu, while maximum Attack investment along with Choice Band makes it a fearsome wallbreaker.

Galarian Zapdos does a great job at weakening teams for cleaners such as Buzzwole and Terrakion. It should avoid directly switching into walls, as they could inflict status conditions that greatly harm its wallbreaking potential, or into most attacks, which can hurt its longevity when combined with Brave Bird recoil. Fighting teams appreciate its ability to switch into Fighting- and Ground-type attacks like Close Combat and Earthquake from Choice Scarf Buzzwole and Excadrill, respectively. Cobalion acts as a great partner for Galarian Zapdos with its ability to switch into Fairy- and Ice-type attacks, provide Stealth Rock support, and provide Thunder Wave support so it can outspeed threats like Dragapult, Latios, and Tornadus-T. It can also bring Galarian Zapdos in with Volt Switch, and, in return, it appreciates Galarian Zapdos switching into Fighting- and Ground-type attacks. Keldeo can help Galarian Zapdos in dealing with physical walls like Hippowdon and Skarmory a bit better, and it appreciates Galarian Zapdos's ability to deal with special walls such as Blissey and Slowking. Choice Scarf Terrakion can clean through teams weakened by Galarian Zapdos and also helps in dealing with Flying-types such as Zapdos and Tornadus-T, which would otherwise trouble Galarian Zapdos, or weakening shared checks with a Swords Dance set. Choice Scarf Buzzwole can clean through teams weakened by Galarian Zapdos thanks to Beast Boost while also having Earthquake and Leech Life to beat Electric- and Psychic-types like Zeraora and Choice Specs Latios. Hawlucha can be used alongside Galarian Zapdos for dual Flying-type STAB move spam.

Moltres-Galar.overview:
Dark

Galarian Moltres is an excellent addition to Dark teams due to its Flying typing providing them with immunity to Ground-type attacks such as Excadrill's Earthquake and ability to take on Fighting-types and other threats such as Keldeo, Tapu Bulu, and Azumarill with Hurricane. Galarian Moltres is an excellent stallbreaker that can take advantage of passive defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss with Substitute. Agility allows Galarian Moltres to become a threat to offensive teams, while Nasty Plot allows it to devastate defensive cores such as Amoonguss and Toxapex, letting it to threaten a multitude of teams. However, Galarian Moltres relies on getting Nasty Plot boosts before it can get across meaningful damage. Galarian Moltres's Speed tier also leaves a lot to be desired, as it is threatened by a multitude of faster attackers like Garchomp and Tapu Lele.
Moltres-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Dark

Heavy-Duty Boots allows Galarian Moltres to switch into Stealth Rock freely. Substitute can be used over Agility, allowing Galarian Moltres to set up on Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss more easily. Air Slash can be used over Hurricane for its better accuracy; however, the power difference is noticeable, such as not being able to OHKO Garchomp after a Nasty Plot boost.

Checks and Counters

Dark

Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon such as Garchomp, Choice Specs Zapdos, and Weavile can easily take out Galarian Moltres. However, after an Agility boost, it can easily take on some of these threats.

Status: Paralysis severely limits Galarian Moltres's ability to take on slower Pokemon such as Nidoking and Azumarill and makes it more susceptible to being revenge killed, while being poisoned, especially by Toxic, puts Galarian Moltres on a timer.

Phazers: Haze users such as Toxapex and Mantine prevent Galarian Moltres from being able to break through teams with ease. Whirlwind and Roar users such as Hippowdon and Swampert can phaze Galarian Moltres and remove its boosts.

Faster Taunt Users: Faster Taunt users such as Tapu Koko, Cobalion, and Zarude prevent Galarian Moltres from accumulating Nasty Plot boosts, allowing their teammates to more easily take it on.

Specially Defensive Walls: Blissey and Tyranitar easily wall Galarian Moltres, even after several Nasty Plot boosts, and threaten it back with Seismic Toss from Blissey or Rock Blast and Toxic from Tyranitar.

sets.name: Double Dance (Dark)
sets.description:
Nasty Plot allows Galarian Moltres to become a powerful wallbreaker that is able to take on defensive types like Poison in their entirety and threaten physical walls such as Hippowdon, Galarian Corsola, Slowbro, and Mandibuzz. Hurricane allows Galarian Moltres to target Dark-resistant foes such as Kommo-o, Tapu Bulu, and Zarude. Fiery Wrath is Galarian Moltres's most spammable attack, especially with its chance to flinch foes, and targets Pokemon such as Aegislash, Celesteela, and Heatran. Agility allows Galarian Moltres to outspeed threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill, Kingdra in rain, Regieleki, and Choice Scarf Terrakion and makes it a great sweeper against other offensive teams. Berserk allows Galarian Moltres to take advantage of its good natural bulk by boosting its Special Attack on top of Nasty Plot boosts. Maximum Speed investment alongside a Timid nature allow Galarian Moltres to outspeed threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill outside of sand, Nidoking, Togekiss, and Swords Dance Landorus-T.

All of Galarian Moltres's teammates appreciate its ability to take on walls such as Amoonguss and Toxapex with Substitute and Nasty Plot and threaten Fighting-types such as Keldeo. Grimmsnarl provides dual screens, giving Galarian Moltres ample opportunities to set up. Tyranitar can switch into powerful special attacks such as Choice Specs Kyurem's Ice Beam and Choice Specs Zapdos's Thunderbolt for Galarian Moltres and set Stealth Rock. Bisharp helps take on Fairy-types such as Clefable for Galarian Moltres and acts as a revenge killer, picking off weakened threats such as Choice Specs Zapdos with Sucker Punch. Weavile can break through Flying- and Dragon-types such as Tornadus-T and Dragonite and pick off weakened faster threats such as Choice Scarf Landorus-T with Ice Shard. Zarude takes care of Water- and Ground-types such as Swampert, Tapu Fini, Hippowdon, and Gastrodon and forms a stallbreaking core with Galarian Moltres to beat defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex. Krookodile provides an Electric immunity and can stop Hippowdon and Swampert from setting entry hazards with Taunt.

Dragonite.overview:
Dragon

Dragonite is a powerful wallbreaker and setup sweeper thanks to its high Attack stat and access to Dragon Dance. Its Multiscale ability paired with Heavy-Duty Boots allows it to check many Pokemon, since it can withstand nearly any attack from full HP. It has solid coverage options in Earthquake and Fire Punch to hit Pokemon such as Heatran and Celesteela, respectively, and access to a strong priority move in Extreme Speed to pick off weakened foes. However, Extreme Speed can't fully compensate for Dragonite's mediocre Speed even after setting up. At +1, it is left outsped by fast Pokemon such as Zeraora and Dragapult if running an Adamant nature, and many Choice Scarf users even with Jolly. Once it has revealed its moveset, it becomes easier to check, as, if it's lacking Earthquake, it gets walled by Heatran and neutered by Haze Toxapex, whereas without Fire Punch it can't touch Pokemon such as Celesteela and Ferrothorn. Dragonite may also struggle to find safe opportunities to switch in because it risks getting its Multiscale broken.

Flying

Multiscale allows Dragonite to tank most unboosted hits from full health, and Heavy-Duty Boots keeps it from getting chipped by Stealth Rock; this endurance makes Dragonite a fearsome setup sweeper. Extreme Speed allows it to revenge kill faster offensive threats to Flying-type teams, such as Alolan Raichu and Kingdra. Flying-type teams also appreciate its part-Dragon typing, which gives it many notable resistances, including Water and Fire against Pokemon such as Urshifu-R, Volcarona, and Victini. It also gives a neutrality to Electric. However, Dragonite has very limited opportunities to safely switch into the field due to the risk of breaking Multiscale. It is susceptible to status conditions such as burn and poison, which easily break Multiscale. Dragonite also struggles with breaking through walls such as Slowbro, Galarian Weezing, and Galarian Corsola, as they can threaten to burn it.
Dragonite.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Dragonite can use a Choice Band set for immediate power and a fourth coverage move; however, without Heavy-Duty Boots, Dragonite can't preserve its Multiscale if Stealth Rock is up and, as a result, loses a lot of utility.

Flying

Choice Band is an alternative set that gives immediate power; however, this leaves Dragonite and Multiscale susceptible to Stealth Rock. Roost over Extreme Speed or a coverage move is another plausible set, but the trade results in less damage output and potency overall. An Adamant nature can be opted for on sets that utilize Fire Punch over Earthquake, as outspeeding Tapu Koko after a Dragon Dance boost is no longer necessary.

Checks and Counters

Dragon

Ice-types: Due to Dragonite's 4x weakness to Ice, Pokemon that carry Ice-type coverage pose huge threats to it, and STAB Ice-type attacks can sometimes even OHKO it through Multiscale.

Fairy-types: Dragonite doesn't run any coverage for Fairy-types, so naturally it has a hard time dealing with Pokemon such as Galarian Weezing and Clefable.

Status: Dragonite hates getting inflicted with any status because it severely hinders its sweeping capabilities.

Physically Defensive Walls: Dragonite may struggle getting past many physical walls such as Hippowdon, Galarian Corsola, and Mandibuzz because they're bulky enough to take a boosted attack and threaten it in various ways.

Flying

Status: Dragonite is susceptible to being burned or poisoned, since the former halves its Attack and both break its Multiscale, making it harder to set up. Paralysis also harms it greatly, leaving it unable to outspeed many threats after a boost and more easily revenge killed.

Sand and Hail: Both sand and hail immediately and automatically break Multiscale.

Physically Defensive Walls: Dragonite has a hard time breaking through physically defensive Pokemon such as Galarian Weezing and Galarian Corsola, even after Dragon Dance boosts.

Knock Off: As Dragonite heavily relies on Heavy-Duty Boots to ameliorate its weakness to Stealth Rock, Knock Off heavily cripples it.

sets.name: Dragon Dance (Dragon)
sets.description:
Dragon Dance gives Dragonite the necessary power to break through opposing teams. It should be used late-game once the opposing team has been weakened. Outrage is its strongest STAB attack, dealing massive damage to anything that doesn't resist it. It should be used carefully, as it locks Dragonite in for a few turns. Extreme Speed allows Dragonite to pick off weakened Pokemon without taking damage and deal with fast threats such as Weavile and Tapu Koko. Earthquake hits Steel-types that resist its other moves such as Heatran, Aegislash, and Melmetal. Alternatively, Fire Punch can be used to hit Celesteela and Ferrothorn. Heavy-Duty Boots relieves Dragonite of worrying about Stealth Rock so it can keep its Multiscale. An Adamant nature can be used for maximum power, whereas Jolly can be used to outspeed Pokemon such as Zeraora and Dragapult at +1 Speed.

As a setup sweeper, Dragonite appreciates teammates that help weaken the opposing team as much as possible before going for the win. Garchomp's Stealth Rock aids in this goal, as it makes it easier for Dragonite to get KOs. Hydreigon is able to threaten Steel-type teams with its coverage, giving Dragonite an easier time due to its exploitable moveset. Dragalge switches in well on most Fairy-type attacks that threaten Dragonite thanks to its Poison typing and good Special Defense. It can also set up Toxic Spikes to whittle down the opposing team for Dragonite. Kyurem is a strong breaker and does well in matchups where Dragonite struggles such as Poison, Ground, and Water. Latias provides Healing Wish support, which is extremely valuable for a setup sweeper such as Dragonite. Dragapult can spread status in the form of Will-O-Wisp and Thunder Wave and punch holes in teams with its attacks to open up for Dragonite to clean.

sets.name: Offensive Dragon Dance (Flying)
sets.description:
Dragon Dance makes Dragonite both a setup sweeper and a late-game cleaner. Outrage is the best Dragon-type STAB move available to Dragonite, and it can comfortably 2HKO walls such as Slowbro and Hippowdon after a Dragon Dance boost. Extreme Speed gives Dragonite the only priority available on Flying teams, and it can be used to clean up chipped or frail threats such as Alolan Raichu. Earthquake is primarily used to hit Electric-types, such as Tapu Koko and Zeraora, and Pokemon that resist or are immune to Dragon such as Heatran, Jirachi, and Azumarill, as well as hitting targets like Tyranitar and Toxapex super effectively. Fire Punch can be used in lieu of Earthquake to deal with Ferrothorn and Celesteela, since they otherwise completely wall Dragonite. Heavy-Duty Boots makes Dragonite immune to Stealth Rock, allowing it to preserve Multiscale reliably. Thanks to its Jolly nature, it outspeeds several threats such as Tapu Koko, Spectrier, Zeraora, and Dragapult after just one Dragon Dance boost.

Celesteela, Corviknight, and Skarmory can sponge super effective Ice-, Dragon-, Rock-, and Fairy-type attacks for Dragonite with ease. Celesteela notably takes on threatening Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Clefable, and Mimikyu. Corviknight and Skarmory take on Ice-types such as Kyurem and Weavile, respectively. Corviknight is also able to safely bring in Dragonite with U-turn, while Skarmory can provide Spikes support. Landorus-T helps greatly in the Electric matchup, is able to set Stealth Rock, and can provide Knock Off support. Tornadus-T can use Knock Off too, and it can also use Taunt and then pivot into Dragonite. Thundurus-T is a complementary setup sweeper to Dragonite, since it can deal with foes such as Tapu Fini, but it can also act as a reliable revenge killer and great offensive pivot when equipped with a Choice Scarf. Zapdos can Pressure stall and reliably pivot to eventually put bulkier foes such as Slowking in a weakened position. Choice Specs Zapdos and Dragonite deal with each other's threats well. Galarian Moltres aids greatly in matchups like Psychic, Ghost, and Steel, while Galarian Zapdos helps immensely in matchups such as Steel, Dark, and Ice.

sets.name: Stallbreaker
sets.description:
Mew's good bulk combined with its wide array of utility moves and pure Psychic typing makes it a good stallbreaker that can be troublesome for a variety of types such as Steel, Ground, and Psychic to deal with. Its access to moves such as Taunt, Knock Off, and Will-O-Wisp combined with reliable recovery in Roost allows it to break down a variety of defensive Pokemon in the Monotype metagame such as Toxapex, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn, as well as cripple offensive Pokemon such as Excadrill and Duraludon. Taunt is especially important, as it prevents said defensive Pokemon from healing, setting up, spreading status, and setting entry hazards. The given EV spread allows Mew to outspeed Mimikyu and Kyurem-B in order to cripple both before they can move and prevent the latter from using Dragon Dance with Taunt while also outpacing other offensive Pokemon such as Bisharp and Mamoswine.

Mew dislikes dealing with wallbreakers such as Dragapult and Keldeo. Choice Scarf users such as Indeedee and Gardevoir support Mew by revenge killing said wallbreakers, while Mew can break down defensive Pokemon like Corviknight that they struggle with. Indeedee's Normal typing also allows it to switch into Ghost-type moves such as Gengar and Dragapult's Shadow Ball. Hatterene can utilize its Magic Bounce to reflect entry hazards that wear down and cripple Mew as it switches in. Gardevoir and Hatterene are also good checks to Dark-type Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Weavile that Mew struggles with, while Healing Wish users such as the aforementioned Gardevoir, Indeedee-F, Celebi, and Jirachi can heal Mew if it ever gets worn down or inflicted with status. Using its good defensive typing, Celebi can take Water-type attacks such as Seismitoad and Keldeo's Hydro Pump under rain, and in return it appreciates Mew's ability to Taunt Defoggers such as Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Pelipper in order to keep its Stealth Rock on the field.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Mew's access to Nasty Plot and good coverage options make it a good setup sweeper capable of threatening many types like Steel, Grass, and Poison. Fire Blast is extremely important, as it allows Mew to hit Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight, Aegislash, and Bisharp for super effective damage, therefore making it amazing in the Steel matchup when set up. Volt Switch is used for pivoting and is particularly useful for breaking Mimikyu's Disguise under Psychic Terrain while keeping Mew healthy. A Colbur Berry allows Mew to take Bisharp's Sucker Punch while helping with other Dark-type attacks. Generally, Mew should find passive Pokemon like Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight to set up on and force out with its attacks.

As a setup sweeper, Mew appreciates support from Pokemon like Jirachi and Orbeetle. The former can set Stealth Rock for it, while the latter can set Sticky Web, both supporting Mew by chipping or slowing down foes, respectively. Steath Rock is particularily notable for securing the OHKO on Corviknight at +2 with Fire Blast, as well as breaking Focus Sash on Pokemon such as Cloyster, Dugtrio, and Polteageist that could otherwise stop Mew. Orbeetle can also set dual screens to help Mew set up. Healing Wish users such as Gardevoir, Indeedee-F, Celebi, and Jirachi also support Mew by healing it when it is chipped or statused, giving it more setup opportunities. The aforementioned offensive Pokemon like Indeedee, Hatterene, and Gardevoir make good partners for Mew by supporting it offensively. Indeedee is a strong wallbreaker that can set Psychic Terrain for Mew, protecting it from priority and boosting its Psychic, while Hatterene can keep entry hazards off the field with Magic Bounce, Gardevoir can revenge kill faster threats, and both of these Pokemon are able to take on Dark-type Pokemon for Mew. In return, these offensive Pokemon appreciate Mew's ability to set up and deal with Steel-type Pokemon like Corviknight and Aegislash reliably with Fire Blast.

sets.name: Xatu (Flying)
sets.description:
With its ability in Magic Bounce deterring Stealth Rock and dual screens support for teammates, Xatu acts as a great utility support Pokemon for hyper offensive Flying-type teams. It provides threatening setup sweepers like Gyarados and Hawlucha not only with dual screen support, but also with Thunder Wave to slow down faster Pokemon and open up more room for offensive teammates to shine. U-turn allows it to switch into the desired teammate after setting up dual screens without losing much momentum for the team. Xatu should be preserved, as Magic Bounce is crucial for Flying-type teams and its Speed tier lets it repeatedly set up dual screens throughout the game. Maximum Speed investment allows Xatu to be as fast as possible to set up dual screens, while the rest of the spread improves its overall bulk to paralyze threats like Barraskewda and Togekiss for the team when behind dual screen support.

Offensive behemoths like Gyarados, Hawlucha, Braviary, and Charizard all make exceptional teammates for Xatu, as they all appreciate dual screen and Thunder Wave support to aid them in setting up. Xatu should be kept away from Knock Off users like Clefable and Whimsicott, as without its Light Clay, the number of turns its teammates can take advantage of dual screens support is reduced. Additionally, Xatu should be kept away from faster Dark-, Ice-, and Ghost-types that can outright OHKO it and instead should pivot out with U-turn on their predicted switch in.

sets.name: Belly Drum (Fairy)
sets.description:
Azumarill's ability in Huge Power, coupled with a fantastic setup move in Belly Drum and powerful priority in Aqua Jet, turns it into a dangerous setup sweeper in matchups such as those against Steel and Fire teams that Fairy teams otherwise struggle with. Belly Drum alongside Aqua Jet allows Azumarill to clean through the opponent's team with its priority. Knock Off allows Azumarill to hit Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Toxapex and support the team by removing items such as Chansey's Eviolite. Substitute is used to dodge status from Pokemon such as Toxapex and Torkoal, allowing Azumarill to more securely set up Belly Drum. Play Rough hits Pokemon such as Mandibuzz and Pokemon that resist Aqua Jet such as Keldeo. 4 HP EVs ensure that Azumarill can always use its Sitrus Berry after a Belly Drum. An Adamant nature allows it to threaten Ferrothorn and Toxapex after using Belly Drum. Belly Drum is most ideally set up behind the dual screens that Klefki provides, and setting up two layers of Spikes with Klefki allows Azumarill to always OHKO Ferrothorn and Toxapex after a Belly Drum by using Knock Off. Additionally, Azumarill should use Substitute whenever a slower Pokemon can only threaten it with status, such as Toxapex running Toxic.

Klefki offers mandatory support for Azumarill, as it provides dual screens for Azumarill to set up Belly Drum more easily, and its Spikes support allows Azumarill to clean more easily late-game. Klefki can also check threats such as Scizor with Foul Play. Togekiss paired with Azumarill allows Fairy teams to take on the Steel matchup, with Togekiss breaking through Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Skarmory with Fire Blast and Azumarill cleaning through the rest of the team with Belly Drum in tandem with Knock Off for Corviknight and Aqua Jet for Excadrill. Togekiss can also break through Grass-type Pokemon such as Rillaboom for Azumarill and break past stall Pokemon such as Toxapex and Mandibuzz with tools such as Nasty Plot and Thunder Wave. Hatterene can take on Poison-type Pokemon for Azumarill such as Toxapex and Galarian Weezing as well as block hazards that could add to Belly Drum's health penalty thanks to Magic Bounce. Galarian Weezing can provide fantastic support for Azumarill by setting Toxic Spikes to wear down checks such as Bewear and absorbing the opponent's Toxic Spikes. Additionally, Galarian Weezing can burn physical attackers such as Diggersby. Mimikyu and Grimmsnarl form a physical setup core with Azumarill, as they are able to use Swords Dance and Bulk Up to help Azumarill in both the Psychic and Electric matchups. Additionally, both have strong priority, making the team less dependent on Azumarill's priority to check a multitude of threats including Volcarona, Alolan Raichu, and Gengar. Lastly, Gardevoir can provide Azumarill with a second chance to sweep with Healing Wish.

Slowking.overview:
Water

Slowking has cemented itself as a staple on Water teams due to its impressive special bulk allowing it to switch into threats such as Nidoking and access to Teleport. With Future Sight and Teleport, Slowking can force progress against types like Water and Poison with Urshifu-R. Slowking also has extremely reliable recovery in Slack Off and Regenerator, allowing it to stay healthy throughout the match with ease. Slowking's Psychic typing allows it to stomach Psychic-type attacks such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele's Psychic with ease. While Slowking's special bulk is phenomenal, its physical bulk is lacking and allows physical wallbreakers and setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Bisharp to easily OHKO it. Slowking is also heavily reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots to act as a reliable pivot and can be worn down by entry hazards and Toxic Spikes if they are removed.
Slowking.comments:
Other Options

Water

Ice Beam can be run over Scald to target Pokemon such as Dragonite and Substitute Hydreigon. Calm Mind Slowking can be used on stall Water teams to answer Kyurem; however, it is not worth using on any balance or offensive team.

Checks and Counters

Water

Physical Wallbreakers and Setup Sweepers: Zeraora, Bisharp, Tapu Bulu, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and Swords Dance Garchomp can easily break through Slowking due to its poor physical defense. However, none of these Pokemon can safely switch into Slowking because they fear being burned by Scald.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers such as Mew, Tapu Fini, and Tornadus-T can prevent Slowking from pivoting with Teleport or using Slack Off. They can also remove Slowking's Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off, forcing it to take chip damage from entry hazards whenever it tries to pivot into battle.

Toxic: Being poisoned by Toxic makes it more difficult for Slowking to switch into special attackers such as Tapu Lele and Nidoking and safely bring in a teammate with Teleport.

sets.name: Specially Defensive Pivot (Water)
sets.description:
Scald can be used to fish for burns against Pokemon such as against Corviknight and deter physical attackers such as Bisharp from switching in. Slack Off, Regenerator, and Heavy-Duty Boots help Slowking with its longevity, as the former two provide recovery and the latter protects it from entry hazards like Toxic Spikes. Teleport + Future Sight is a potent combination that allows Slowking to safely bring in an offensive teammate and support them offensively by pressuring foes with an extra attack. Maximum HP and Special Defense investment maximizes Slowking's special bulk, allowing it to reliably switch into attacks like Choice Specs Latios's Draco Meteor and Nidoking's Earth Power or Thunderbolt. A Sassy nature alongside 0 Speed IVs allows Slowking to retain momentum against opposing Slowking with a slower Teleport.

Urshifu-R can take on Steel- and Dark-types for Slowking such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight, Bisharp, Tyranitar, and Mandibuzz. Urshifu-R and Slowking form a potent offensive core that can make progress against types such as Water and Poison by using Future Sight, bringing in Urshifu-R safely with Teleport, and forcing a Pokemon to switch into both its attacks and Future Sight. While not as good as Urshifu-R, Keldeo can outspeed threats such as Zarude. Swampert is an Electric immunity, can take on Electric-types such as Zeraora with Earthquake, and provides Stealth Rock, which in tandem with Future Sight can wear down foes quickly. Toxapex can form a Regenerator core with Slowking, absorbing physical attacks such as Rillaboom's Grassy Glide and retaliating with Poison Jab. Choice Scarf Tapu Fini can take on Dark- and Dragon-types such as Zarude, Hydreigon, and Kyurem for Slowking. Additionally, it can cripple other walls by locking them into one attack with Trick or removing items such as Toxapex's Black Sludge with Knock Off. Crawdaunt can put in work against Psychic and Ghost teams, taking on opposing walls such as Slowbro and Galarian Corsola. Rotom-W can clear entry hazards with Defog, act as a revenge killer with Choice Scarf, and dent Choice Specs Zapdos. It can also use Trick to lock foes into an unfavorable move.

Slowking-Galar.overview:
Poison

Assault Vest Galarian Slowking is a great specially defensive wall for Poison teams that sponges special attacks from Pokemon like Latios, Kyurem, and Thundurus-T. It can also use its Psychic neutrality to switch into Psychic-type attacks from threats to Poison like Tapu Lele and Latias. It forms a Regenerator core with Toxapex and Amoonguss, making them extremely hard to break through. Its many coverage moves keep it from being setup fodder and improve a number of matchups for Poison like Flying, Dragon, and Fighting. Its lackluster physical bulk leaves it forced out by wallbreakers like Bisharp, Cinderace, Excadrill, and Zeraora.
Slowking-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Poison

Psyshock is an option over Future Sight to prevent Calm Mind and Quiver Dance sweepers like Spectrier and Keldeo from setting up.

Checks and Counters

Poison

Knock Off: Losing Assault Vest to Pokemon like Alolan Raichu and Clefable worsens Galarian Slowking's ability to take on special attackers.

Setup Sweepers: Galarian Slowking has a hard time dealing with many setup sweepers, especially Substitute + Calm Mind users like Jirachi, Spectrier, and Suicune.

Super Effective Attacks: Dark-types such as Crawdaunt, Krookodile, and Weavile threaten to KO Galarian Slowking with their STAB moves. Similarly, Ghost-types like Dragapult, Mimikyu, and Gengar force Galarian Slowking out, but it can often handle an attack or two from special super effective attackers. Ground-types like Excadrill, Garchomp, and Landorus-T can OHKO Galarian Slowking with Earthquake, but the latter two fear switching into Ice Beam.

Physical Attackers: Galarian Slowking is unable to withstand attacks from Pokemon like Zeraora, Dragonite, and Excadrill because of its low Defense.

Defensive Pokemon: None of Galarian Slowking's attacks can overcome walls with reliable recovery like Blissey, Gastrodon, and Mew.

sets.name: Assault Vest (Poison)
sets.description:
Future Sight in conjunction with its other attacks helps Galarian Slowking break through bulkier Pokemon like Toxapex and Cradily and targets wallbreakers like Dragapult and Zeraora. Sludge Bomb immediately damages special attackers and has a nifty chance to poison defensive Pokemon like Mantine and Zapdos, making them a lot easier to beat. Sludge Bomb is also needed to break Substitute from Kyurem, which can threaten Poison with Earth Power and Ice Beam. Earthquake helps with Poison- and Steel-types like Dragalge, Nidoking, and most importantly Heatran, which could trap and remove this set otherwise. Flamethrower with Earthquake gives Poison teams a better chance in the Steel matchup, specifically allowing Galarian Slowking to hit Ferrothorn and other Steel-types like Scizor, Skarmory, and Magnezone. Ice Beam hits Flying- and Dragon-types like Galarian Zapdos, Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Hydreigon, but it often needs to catch them as they switch in. A Sassy nature avoids weakening Earthquake.

All of Galarian Slowking's teammates appreciate its ability to switch in on special attacks from Pokemon like Heatran, often Psychic-types like Alakazam and Choice Scarf Latias. Nidoking can set Stealth Rock, provide an Electric immunity for Regieleki, and get rid of defensive Pokemon and physical attackers like Mantine, Aegislash, and Dragonite. Toxapex and Amoonguss form a Regenerator core alongside Galarian Slowking, making them harder to KO. Toxapex beats setup sweepers like Cinderace and Dragapult with Haze and physical attackers like Bisharp and Weavile. Amoonguss helps the team switch into Earthquake from Mold Breaker Excadrill and avert Swords Dance sweeps with Foul Play. Furthermore, it spreads status with Spore and Stun Spore and helps Galarian Slowking with physical attackers like Zeraora. Galarian Weezing gets rid of entry hazards with Defog, has Levitate for Ground-types like Garchomp and Landorus-T, and has Strange Stream to threaten Dark- and Dragon-types like Dragapult, Hydreigon, Weavile, and Zarude. While Galarian Slowking can withstand most Psychic-type moves, using Drapion prevents the team from being swept by a Calm Mind sweeper like Latias or Jirachi and gives the team Knock Off to remove items and help with Ghost-types like Spectrier and Aegislash.

Scizor.overview:
Bug

Scizor is an essential sweeper for Bug teams due to its solid bulk, Steel typing, and access to recovery in Roost giving it ample setup opportunities with Swords Dance. With a spammable Technician-boosted STAB move in Bullet Punch and useful coverage in Knock Off and Superpower, Scizor is able to greatly threaten common types such as Fairy, Ice, Flying, and Dragon. Scizor's typing and access to reliable recovery in Roost allow it to check Psychic-, Fairy-, and Poison-types that Bug teams can often struggle against, such as Tapu Lele and Nihilego. However, Scizor's coverage is very one-dimensional, causing it to struggle in other matchups such as Water, Electric, and Fire. Furthermore, it is reliant on Bullet Punch for its damage output against faster targets, meaning that it can be easily revenge killed by Pokemon that resist Steel such as Heatran and Urshifu-R. Scizor's exploitable 4x weakness to Fire also limits its ability to switch into defensive Pokemon carrying Fire coverage such as Celesteela and Galarian Slowking.
Scizor.comments:
Other Options

Bug

Life Orb can be used over Metal Coat for more damage at the cost of longevity. Dual Wingbeat is an option that does more neutral damage than Bullet Punch thanks to Technician and hits Amoonguss, Urshifu-R, and Substitute users like Kyurem, while Psycho Cut can cover Poison-types like Toxapex. However, these are usually less useful than Roost or Superpower. A Choice Band set can be used for more initial power, but it makes Scizor much easier to play around once the set is known.

Checks and Counters

Bug

Walls: Physical walls such as Hippowdon, Skarmory, and Toxapex take negligible damage from Scizor's boosted attacks and can get rid of its boosts through phazing moves or Haze.

Steel-resistant Pokemon: Water-, Fire-, Electric-, and Steel-types, including Urshifu-R, Volcanion, Zapdos, and Celesteela, do not fear Scizor's Bullet Punch and threaten Scizor with their powerful attacks or super effective coverage.

Status: Burn from Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Sableye is crippling for Scizor because it forces it to have multiple Swords Dance boosts to deal significant damage. While Scizor is not reliant on its Speed, paralysis annoys it because it prevents it from safely healing with Roost or getting guaranteed damage versus offensive threats.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Bug)
sets.description:
Swords Dance boosts Scizor's attack, enabling it to OHKO offensive threats like Dragapult and Tapu Koko with Bullet Punch. Knock Off is a utility move that hits Steel- and Psychic-types such as Aegislash, Celesteela, and Slowbro. Roost keeps Scizor healthy, allowing it to set up with Swords Dance and attack multiple times. Superpower is a useful coverage option that hits Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Excadrill. Metal Coat provides the most damage on Bullet Punch without drawbacks. 216 Speed EVs allow Scizor to outspeed Jolly Azumarill, as well as Adamant Bewear and Aegislash.

All Pokemon on Bug teams appreciate Scizor's wallbreaking capability and defensive utility. Volcarona is the primary partner for Scizor, as it can help deal with Steel-types such as Skarmory while also being able to sweep most types, including Poison and Electric, after Scizor breaks through them. In return, Scizor can handle Rock-types such as Tyranitar and Nihilego. Sticky Web support from Araquanid and Shuckle can help make up for Scizor's middling Speed, and Araquanid also provides a switch-in to Fire-types. Stealth Rock and Spikes support from Shuckle, Armaldo, and Golisopod can ease Scizor's wallbreaking by spreading chip damage, and Golisopod additionally provides utility against defensive teams through Knock Off and Taunt. Galvantula and Vikavolt can break Water-types that Scizor struggles against such as Toxapex and Gastrodon. Guts Heracross can threaten Steel-types such as Heatran and Celesteela for Scizor while also threatening Rotom-W. Buzzwole is another cleaner that appreciates Scizor's wallbreaking that can sweep against types like Steel and Fire, matchups where Scizor is less useful.

sets.name: Entry Hazards Lead (Bug)
sets.description:
Set Description

Shuckle is the primary entry hazard setter for Bug teams, with its access to Stealth Rock and Sticky Web. Since Shuckle is a utility Pokemon, Encore is used as an insurance against setup Pokemon such as Gyarados and Hawlucha, which can potentially exploit Shuckle. Toxic is used to cripple bulky Pokemon such as Hippowdon. Knock Off can be used as an alternative to cripple Pokemon such as Corviknight and Ferrothorn by removing their item. Mental Herb is used to bypass Taunt users such as Froslass and Sableye in order to allow Shuckle to at least set up either Stealth Rock or Sticky Web; otherwise, it is forced to Struggle under Taunt.

Strong wallbreakers such as Centiskorch and Durant appreciate Stealth Rock, as they can wallbreak more consistently with the chip damage. Centiskorch greatly benefits from Sticky Web, as its Speed is mediocre as well. Durant can outspeed common Choice Scarf users with Sticky Web up on the opposing side of the field, such as Dracozolt and Excadrill. Sticky Web also frees teammates like Galvantula and Vikavolt from running it, allowing them to use more offensive sets.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter (Rock)
sets.description:
Shuckle is essential for Rock-type teams because of its access to Stealth Rock and Sticky Web. By using Sticky Web, Shuckle helps its teammates greatly with outpacing threats such as Jirachi. Stealth Rock is great to help wear down Pokemon on the switch in. Knock Off helps with depriving bulky Pokemon like Hippowdon of Leftovers recovery and Duraludon of Choice items. Toxic is an option over Knock Off to put Pokemon such as Mantine, Kommo-o, and Slowbro on a timer. Encore is great to lock setup Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Scizor into Nasty Plot or Swords Dance and can also be useful against bulky Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Galarian Corsola to lock them into the first move they use, which forces them to switch out. Mental Herb is used to bypass Taunt from Pokemon like Froslass and Kommo-o once, therefore letting Shuckle set entry hazards up. Use Shuckle early-game to get Sticky Web down so its teammates can have an easier time with outpacing Pokemon or setting up. 252 HP and 252 Special Defense EVs alongside a Calm nature allow Shuckle to set up entry hazards more easily due to it being able to tank attacks.

All teammates appreciate Shuckle for its ability to use entry hazards to help them outpace or chip down the opposing Pokemon. Barbaracle is a good setup sweeper that can take care of Sand Rush Excadrill thanks to its part Water-typing and benefit from Shuckle's Sticky Web, giving it more safe setup opportunities with Shell Smash and allowing it to outpace Excadrill in sand along with Kyurem and Choice Scarf Darmanitan. Terrakion is a good Choice Scarf user for when Sticky Web has not been set up or has been removed with Defog or Rapid Spin. Terrakion's part-Fighting typing is useful in the Steel- and Dark-type matchup for dealing with Excadrill, Bisharp, and Hydreigon. Coalossal is a great Rapid Spin user because of its bulk and can stack entry hazards with Shuckle with Spikes. Tyranitar is another setup sweeper that can greatly help with the Ghost- and Psychic-type matchups because it can take advantage of Stick Web, set up with Dragon Dance, and take care of threats such as Gengar and Gardevoir. Rhyperior is a much-needed partner to give the team a way to deal with Corviknight and Skarmory via Smack Down and Earthquake, and can also use its Earthquake and Fire Punch to greatly help with taking care of Steel-types like Jirachi, Excadrill, and Bisharp.

sets.name: Stealth Rock (Ice)
sets.description:
Piloswine performs the role of a defensive Stealth Rock setter for Ice-type teams. Its decent natural bulk not only allows it to switch into Pokemon like defensive Tyranitar and Life Orb Mimikyu, but it also lets it set up Stealth Rock efficiently. Thanks to its ability in Thick Fat and Eviolite boosting its defenses, it is able to check threatening Fire-type Pokemon like Charizard and Centiskorch for Ice-type teams. As most Fire-type attack users are specially-oriented, Piloswine becomes more useful as a specially defensive Pokemon for Ice teams. With Stealth Rock, Piloswine is able to aid offensive Pokemon like Galarian Darmanitan, Cloyster, and Weavile to score easier KOs. Rock Slide allows it to beat the aforementioned Fire-type Pokemon. Ice Shard allows it to deal with Substitute Hydreigon and it can also be used to pick off weakened Pokemon. Maximum Special Defense investment along with its ability in Thick Fat lets it take Fire-type moves for the team, while Maximum HP investment is used to improve its overall bulk.

Galarian Darmanitan is a fantastic wallbreaker that appreciates Stealth Rock support to wear down defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Toxapex for it. It also loves having Piloswine as an option to pivot into with its fast U-turn against a defensive threat. With Flare Blitz, Galarian Darmanitan can beat Steel-type Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Bronzong for Piloswine. Mamoswine is able to utilize an offensive Choice Band set to wallbreak thanks to Piloswine taking up the role of a Stealth Rock setter. Piloswine, however, is susceptible to Knock Off, hence Avalugg acts as a good defensive sponge for it while also acting as a Rapid Spin user for the team. Piloswine's weakness against Water-type Pokemon can be covered by using Water Absorb Lapras with Freeze-Dry, as it can also drastically improve the team's matchup against Water-type teams. Vanilluxe can provide Aurora Veil support to further bolster Piloswine's defensive capabilities.

sets.name: Defensive Wall (Ghost)
sets.description:
Galarian Corsola is a physically defensive wall whose primary purpose on Ghost teams is to set up Stealth Rock and neuter physical attackers with a combination of Will-O-Wisp and Strength Sap, which also is its form of recovery. Night Shade prevents Galarian Corsola from becoming Taunt bait and enables it to chip down foes. Its EVs and Eviolite allow it to be as physically bulky as possible, allowing it to take on threats such as Gyarados. Cursed Body can make Galarian Corsola more difficult to handle, as it can disable coverage to attack it, making it harder to KO.

Jellicent and Sableye appreciate Galarian Corsola's ability to form a strong defensive core with them and whittle down foes for offensive teammates. Jellicent can switch into Water-type attacks for it such as Lapras's Hydro Pump, while Sableye can cripple setup sweepers with Prankster Taunt as well as shut down a boosted Gyarados with Will-O-Wisp. All the offensive Pokemon on Ghost teams appreciate Galarian Corsola's ability to set up Stealth Rock as it makes it easier to break through opposing Pokemon. In return, Galarian Corsola specifically appreciates Mimikyu's ability to take on Dark-type Pokemon that threaten it such as Hydreigon. Thanks to its ability to set Spikes, Froslass forms a good entry hazard stacking core with Galarian Corsola.

Mantine.overview:
Water

Mantine's superb Special Defense and HP stats and access to utility moves such as Defog, Haze, and Roost make it a great wall on Water balance teams, taking on foes such as Volcarona, Hydreigon, and Hatterene. It can form a potent defensive core with Pokemon such as Swampert, Slowking, and Toxapex. Mantine's Flying typing provides a key neutrality to Grass as well as an immunity to Ground; this makes it effective against foes such as Swampert and Choice Scarf Excadrill locked into Earthquake, which its teammates appreciate. It's held back by its its 4x weakness to Electric, making it susceptible to Pokemon such as Victini and Nidoking that carry Electric-type coverage. Mantine's passivity also leads to a tremendous loss of momentum whenever it enters the field. Special wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele and Choice Specs Zapdos take advantage of this, being able to freely switch in on Mantine and release powerful attacks that can severely damage Mantine or its teammates.

Flying

Mantine is a solid Defogger for Flying teams due to its immunity to Water-type moves and access to Haze and Roost. Furthermore, Mantine's high Special Defence allows it to pivot into threats like Blacephalon, Choice Scarf Tapu Fini, and Tapu Lele. Mantine notably is the only Water absorber on Flying, checking offensive Water-types like Urshifu-R and Barraskewda. However, Mantine is extremely passive and is threatened by offensive Pokemon such as Bisharp, Zapdos, and Kyurem. Mantine also faces competition with other Defoggers like Tornadus-T and Corviknight because of its lack of momentum.
Mantine.comments:
Other Options

Water

Toxic can be used over Haze; however, this makes Mantine setup fodder for foes that are either immune to Toxic or use Substitute, such as Spectrier. Mantine can also use Water Veil as an ability, preventing Spectrier from burning it.

Flying

Toxic may be used over Haze on Mantine to reduce its passivity and allows it to deal with Volcanion and opposing Mantine. However, this prevents Mantine from checking setup sweepers like Volcarona and Cinderace. Defog can be dropped for Toxic, but this forces one of Mantine's teammates to run Defog. The other EVs can also be placed in Special Defense along with a Calm nature to better handle special attackers, but the reduced Defense prevents Mantine from safely checking Cinderace and Azumarill.

Checks and Counters

Water

Physical Wallbreakers: Many physical attackers such as Choice Band Rillaboom and Bisharp can easily threaten Mantine with either an OHKO or severe damage due to Mantine's average Defense stat.

Stallbreakers: Many stallbreakers such as Tapu Fini and Mew prevent Mantine from using Defog and restoring health via Roost.

Toxic: Many common walls such as Mandibuzz and Toxapex can Toxic stall Mantine, as it normally doesn't run Toxic itself. Mandibuzz also has access to Taunt, letting it obstruct Mantine from healing off Toxic damage with Roost. Toxic also generally puts Mantine on a timer and prevents it from easily coming in and using Defog.

Flying

Toxic: Toxic hinders Mantine's ability to clear entry hazards and reliably check setup sweepers and Water-types.

Heatran: Mantine has to be wary of swapping into Heatran, as it can inflict Toxic on Mantine, trap it with Magma Storm, and inflict with with Taunt to weaken Mantine or forcibly remove it from the match.

Taunt: Taunt users such as Mew, Tapu Fini, and Galarian Moltres can prevent Mantine from doing its role and can take advantage of it by using it as setup bait.

Setup Sweepers: Although Mantine can deal with most setup sweepers, it notably cannot handle certain physical setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Bisharp and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Physical setup sweepers do not appreciate Scald's burn chance, but this can be circumvented by Substitute.

Water-types: Although Mantine can take Water-type attacks from Urshifu-R and Barraskewda, it cannot meaningfully threaten Water-type Pokemon. Because of this, the opposing team can take advantage of Mantine by pivoting defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Slowking on Mantine to force it out, which allows the opponent to pivot the threatening Pokemon in again.

Defensive Pokemon: Mantine cannot threaten defensive Pokemon, as Scald deals negligible damage to Galarian Slowking, Aegislash, and Dragalge, while these Pokemon can cripple Mantine with poison or Toxic.

sets.name: Support (Water)
sets.description:
Set Description

Scald prevents Mantine from being completely passive and prohibits physical attackers such as Dragonite and Dragapult from switching in recklessly, as they risk being burned. Haze prevents Mantine from becoming setup fodder, letting it reliably switch into and deal with setup sweepers like Keldeo, Hatterene, and Volcarona. Roost allows it to consistently wall foes such as Galarian Moltres and Volcarona and reliably clear entry hazards throughout the game. Mantine has enough Speed investment to outpace Adamant Azumarill, allowing it to use Haze before Azumarill attacks it.

Mantine enjoys the presence of Toxapex to take on physical attackers such as Dragapult and Mimikyu. In return, Mantine can check potent special attackers such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Swampert is able to check Electric-types such as Regieleki and Zeraora while also being able to set Stealth Rock. Gastrodon is also an option in lieu of Swampert, as it is able to check prominent threats to Mantine's team such as Tapu Koko while also having reliable recovery. Slowking is able to switch into powerful Psychic-types like Latios and Choice Specs Tapu Lele, which can otherwise overpower Mantine. Urshifu-R and Keldeo also appreciate Mantine switching in on certain Psychic- and Fairy-type special attackers such as Tapu Lele and Hatterene that threaten them. In return, they can defeat foes such as Bisharp and Terrakion, respectively, for Mantine. Wallbreakers such as Crawdaunt and Tapu Fini appreciate Mantine's Defog, which allows them to enter the field safely to defeat walls that pressure Mantine such as Toxapex, Mandibuzz, and Chansey. Mantine also enjoys having Lanturn on its team, as it provides an Electric immunity and Heal Bell support while also taking on Choice Specs Zapdos more reliably and providing slow Volt Switch support to the team. However, it should be noted that Lanturn is primarily seen on stall teams. Setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Tapu Fini, Cloyster, and Suicune welcome Mantine's ability to remove Toxic Spikes, which jeopardize their ability to set up.

sets.name: Utility (Flying)
sets.description:
Haze checks setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Corviknight, and Azumarill. Scald threatens physical attackers with its burn chance. 96 Speed EVs allow Mantine to outspeed Adamant Azumarill.

Landorus-T greatly appreciates Mantine's ability to switch into Water-types such as Urshifu-R. In return, Landorus-T covers for Mantine's Electric weakness by checking Tapu Koko and Zeraora and other threats such as Victini and Jirachi. Celesteela appreciates Mantine's ability to switch into Fire-types such as Blacephalon and Volcarona, and Celesteela repays this by covering for Mantine's weakness to Rock and checking Tyranitar, Alolan Ninetales, and Kyurem. Mantine, Landorus-T, and Celesteela form the defensive backbone of some Flying teams, which allows other teammates to run more offensive sets to pressure the opposing team better. Thundurus-T and Choice Specs Zapdos appreciates Mantine's Defog and removes hindrances such as Volcanion and Toxapex that can cripple Mantine, and the former takes on Electric-type attacks. Galarian Moltres aids in the Steel, Psychic, Poison, and Ghost matchup and can set up on passive defensive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Slowbro, which Mantine struggles with. Galarian Zapdos can remove threats like Kyurem, Bisharp, and Galarian Darmanitan and walls such as Porygon2 and Blissey.

Skarmory.overview:
Steel

Skarmory's typing allows it to easily find itself a spot in Steel teams for providing the much-needed Ground immunity and Fighting neutrality. Skarmory has access to Spikes, making it the primary setter for its team while freeing up Ferrothorn to run more utility options such as Thunder Wave and Stealth Rock. Its high Defense stat and great typing allow Skarmory to check various physically offensive Pokemon such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Urshifu-R with the help of Roost, Rocky Helmet, and Toxic. Moreover, having access to Roost and Toxic sets Skarmory apart from its competitors in Celesteela and Corviknight. Skarmory is an easy target for Electric-types such as Zapdos and Zeraora, which can grab momentum against Skarmory with their respective coverage. Furthermore, Skarmory can be trapped and eliminated by Magnezone, which enables a safer win route for Bulk Up Zeraora, and it is also vulnerable to Fire-type attacks from Pokemon such as Victini, Blacephalon, and Volcarona, which all pose a threat to it. Skarmory's Special Defense is low, making it weak to common special attackers in the tier such as Blacephalon, Dragapult, Hydreigon, and Kyurem. Being unable to touch any Ghost-type Pokemon outside of Toxic causes Skarmory to lose momentum heavily, especially against Substitute users such as non-Choice Specs Aegislash, Dragapult, and Spectrier, which all force it out.

Flying

Often appearing on balance teams, Skarmory's incredible Defense stat allows it to check many physical attackers such as Melmetal and Bisharp for its teammates. Due to its excellent typing, Skarmory can provide a key neutrality to Ice-type attacks, allowing it to check powerful Ice-types such as Mamoswine and Weavile. Skarmory's access to Spikes, Whirlwind, and Roost allows it to carve out a niche for itself on Flying teams. As a result of its low HP and Special Defense, Skarmory is unable to tank resisted hits from special attackers such as Choice Specs Kyurem and Choice Specs Tapu Lele and can be worn down by walls using special attacking moves like Scald from Toxapex. Skarmory faces competition from Corviknight and Celesteela, as they both share the same typing. Corviknight and Celesteela can tank both physical and special attacks, while Skarmory is relegated to tanking physical attacks.
Skarmory.comments:
Other Options

Steel

In offensive structures, using Skarmory as a suicide lead with both Spikes and Stealth Rock paired with a Custap Berry allows it to set up entry hazards for its offensive teammates at the beginning of the game and apply pressure more easily.

Flying

224 HP EVs allow Skarmory to always be at full HP after two turns of Leftovers recovery after Stealth Rock damage, thus enabling it to use Sturdy. However, this spread reduces Skarmory's overall physical bulk and makes it easier to KO.

Checks and Counters

Steel

Ghost-types: Skarmory's only attacking move is Body Press, which is blocked by every Ghost-type Pokemon in the metagame and causes Skarmory to be forced out, especially if it's lacking Whirlwind.

Electric-types: Electric-types can all force out Skarmory with their respective STAB moves. Zapdos and Rotom-W can remove Spikes with Defog, while Magnezone threatens Skarmory with trapping. However, Magnezone must be careful to not take a hit from Body Press on the switch.

Fire-types: Skarmory has no way of handling offensive Fire-types such as Blacephalon, Volcarona, and Heatran, and these Pokemon can easily take advantage of Skarmory. However, the former two need to be careful about Toxic and the latter must be aware of Body Press.

Special Attackers: Special attackers such as Hydreigon, Kyurem, Dragapult, Gengar, and Spectrier can easily break through Skarmory due to its low Special Defense.

Taunt: Fast Taunt users such as Tornadus-T, Tapu Fini, and Heatran can block Skarmory from using Spikes, Whirlwind, and Roost.

Flying

Hatterene: While preventing Skarmory from setting Spikes with Magic Bounce, Hatterene can also use Skarmory as setup fodder.

Special Attackers: Due to Skarmory's low HP and Special Defense, it is 2HKOed from resisted special attacks from foes such as Choice Specs Tapu Lele.

Taunt: Foes such as Mandibuzz and Bulk Up Corviknight are able to inflict Taunt on Skarmory, preventing it from not only setting Spikes but also healing itself via Roost.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Steel)
sets.description:
Skarmory serves as the primary Spikes setter for its team, allowing offensive teammates such as Bisharp and Excadrill to wallbreak more consistently throughout the game. Body Press synergizes well with Skarmory's bulk and is especially helpful in the mirror matchup against Pokemon such as Bisharp, Ferrothorn, Melmetal, and Heatran on the switch, as well against Dark-types such as Weavile, Tyranitar, and Hydreigon. Roost helps Skarmory to stay healthy throughout the match against foes such as Urshifu-R, Excadrill, and Tyranitar. Whirlwind is used to prevent setup from Pokemon such as Garchomp and Dragapult while also generating passive chip damage if Spikes were set beforehand. Toxic can be used over Whirlwind to cripple Pokemon such as Mandibuzz and Mantine. Rocky Helmet complements Skarmory's physical bulk and typing excellently, as contact move users such as Urshifu-R and Weavile as well as U-turn and Flip Turn users such as Landorus-T, Scizor, Swampert, and Barraskewda will all be worn down by it. Sturdy allows Skarmory to set Spikes or use Toxic on a foe that can knock it out from full health if necessary. Furthermore, Sturdy allows Skarmory to deal damage against troublesome Pokemon that threaten Steel teams, such as Hydreigon. An Impish nature and maximum HP and Defense investment make Skarmory as tanky as possible against the aforementioned physical threats such as Urshifu-R, Excadrill, and Landorus-T.

Having access to Spikes makes Skarmory a valuable teammate, as it allows its offensive teammates such as Excadrill, Aegislash, Melmetal, and Bisharp to have an easier time against common walls such as Toxapex, Porygon2, and Ferrothorn. Ferrothorn is one of the best teammates for Skarmory, as the duo form an effective entry hazard-stacking core with Ferrothorn's Stealth Rock. Furthermore, Skarmory can make up for Ferrothorn's weakness to Fighting, while Ferrothorn takes care of Electric-types such as Tapu Koko and Rotom-W for Skarmory and provides a resistance to Water. Heatran provides the much-needed Fire immunity against Pokemon like Blacephalon and Hydreigon, while Skarmory can take on Ground-type attacks such as Earthquake from Garchomp and Excadrill. Furthermore, Heatran's common moves in Toxic and Magma Storm can deal immense chip damage when combined with Skarmory's Spikes. Excadrill takes care of Electric-types such as Tapu Koko and Zeraora if it is holding a Choice Scarf and can remove Stealth Rock with Rapid Spin to preserve Skarmory's Sturdy. Aegislash makes a good partner for Skarmory, as it relieves the pressure from Skarmory to handle Fighting-type attacks. This is especially important against Choice-locked foes such as Urshifu-R, which will have to avoid being heavily punished by Skarmory's Rocky Helmet. Furthermore, Aegislash helps greatly against Psychic-types such as Hatterene and Tapu Lele, which Skarmory generally struggle against. Bisharp's ability in Defiant also deters Defog from Pokemon such as Mantine and Zapdos, and its typing allows it to shine against Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Galarian Slowking, Slowking, Galarian Corsola, and Spectrier.

sets.name: Defensive Spikes (Flying)
sets.description:
Toxic allows Skarmory to punish opposing Defoggers such as Rotom-W and Heavy-Duty Boots Zapdos as they try to switch into it. Whirlwind can be used over it to phaze opposing setup sweepers such as Bisharp and Dragon Dance Dragapult. In conjunction with Skarmory's bulk it can be used to shuffle opposing teams, slowly damaging them via Spikes. Body Press uses Skarmory's enormous Defense stat to hit threats such as Galarian Darmanitan and Tyranitar. Roost provides Skarmory with reliable recovery, allowing it to preserve Sturdy as well as consistently providing an answer to foes such as Cloyster and Excadrill. Rocky Helmet punishes physical attackers as well as pivots that use Flip Turn and U-turn by taking a chunk of their HP. Leftovers allows Skarmory to gain passive recovery, which it in turn gives it more chances to use its ability Sturdy. Sturdy is Skarmory's best ability, as it can allow Skarmory to survive attacks from foes such as Heliolisk and Volcarona when at full HP, and it can proceed to OHKO the former with Body Press. Maximum HP and Defense investment with a Bold nature allows Skarmory to be as bulky as possible, as well as boosting the power of Body Press.

Mantine is an excellent teammate for Skarmory, as its superb Special Defense allows it to wall special attackers such as Volcarona, Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Hydreigon. In return, Skarmory is able to handle foes like Dragonite and Dragapult. Skarmory appreciates the presence of Landorus-T to OHKO threats such as Tapu Koko and Zapdos. Landorus-T can also switch in on foes such as Zapdos after it has been Choice-locked into Thunderbolt. Skarmory then reciprocates this by acting as a switch-in to physical attackers such as Mamoswine that would otherwise OHKO Landorus-T with Icicle Crash. Defensive Zapdos can provide a key neutrality to Electric-type attacks as well as act as a special wall, taking attacks from foes such as Tapu Koko under Electric Terrain. Moreover, it can run a Toxic + Substitute set to wear down opposing walls such as Mandibuzz that Skarmory would find hard to deal with. Skarmory can then assist Zapdos by taking on potent physical attackers such as Swords Dance Terrakion that Zapdos would otherwise fall to. Zapdos can also run a Choice Specs set that appreciates Skarmory's ability to wear down foes such as Slowking with Spikes. Teammates such as Choice Band Galarian Zapdos and Galarian Moltres appreciate the presence of Spikes on the field, with the former potentially OHKOing foes such as Slowbro, Slowking, and Mew and the latter becoming a much more potent sweeper, being able to guarantee an OHKO on foes such as Slowking. In return, Galarian Zapdos is able to prevent foes from removing Spikes via Defog carelessly due to Defiant. Galarian Moltres is able to check the fearsome Spectrier that would otherwise OHKO Skarmory after it has been inflicted with a status condition. Thundurus-T and Dragonite are also good teammates for Skarmory, as both are helped by Spikes chipping away at their respective checks, and the former can absorb Electric-type attacks for it. Knock Off users such as Tornadus-T allow teammates to take advantage of Skarmory's entry hazards, as it can force foes that normally run Heavy-Duty Boots such as Victini and Cinderace to switchin less often. Moreover, Tornadus-T can use Taunt on opposing Defog users such as Mantine and Corviknight to prevent them from ridding the field of Skarmory's Spikes.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Water)
sets.description:
Kingdra performs the role of a threatening Swift Swim user for Water-type teams, threatening various matchups like Bug, Electric, and Dragon. It utilizes Swift Swim to double its Speed under rain to outspeed threats like Galvantula, Choice Scarf Gengar, Choice Scarf Virizion, and Kyurem. Choice Specs strengthens Kingdra's subpar Special Attack to allow it to act as an amazing sweeper and wallbreaker. Under rain, Surf is Kingdra's go-to move, as it is capable of OHKOing certain Pokemon like Zeraora and Urshifu-S. Dragon Pulse is used in situations where Kingdra has to deal safe and reliable damage to Pokemon like Kyurem, Toxapex, and Mantine that may resist or be immune to its Water-type moves. Draco Meteor acts as a nuke towards Pokemon like Keldeo and Amoonguss that would normally eat up whatever Kingdra has to throw at it. Hydro Pump can be used in order to break through Pokemon like Porygon2 and even has a chance to OHKO stallbreaker Mew and Aegislash under rain. Hurricane is also an option over Hydro Pump, as Hurricane is reliable under rain and can potentially OHKO opposing Grass-types such as Virizion, Whimsicott, and Celebi, to name a few. Maximum Special Attack investment along with a Modest nature and maximum Speed investment allow Kingdra to hit as hard as possible while being able take advantage of Swift Swim to outspeed threats to the team.

Rain is required in order to maximize Kingdra's wallbreaking and sweeping abilities, hence why Pelipper is a perfect teammate for it. Pelipper may opt to run a defensive set with Heavy-Duty Boots if Kingdra runs Hurricane, as Pelipper can safely switch out via U-turn in order to provide rain to Kingdra. Pelipper can also run a Choice Specs set to help Kingdra break through Grass-types if Kingdra does not have Hurricane in its moveset. Eject Button Toxapex can also serve as a pivot that is able to support Kingdra by weakening bulkier Pokemon like Porygon2 and Chansey through Toxic Spikes or Toxic support. Pokemon like Tentacruel, Pelipper, and Rotom-W are Pokemon that can be used for entry hazard control and help Kingdra stay healthy throughout the game. Slowking can also be included in the team, as it can pivot Kingdra or other teammates in safely while acting as a special wall at the same time. Seismitoad can also be paired up with Kingdra, as it can set up Stealth Rock to weaken checks to Kingdra like Porygon2 and Chansey while providing an Electric immunity to the team. Late-game sweepers like Choice Band Azumarill, Choice Scarf Dracovish, Keldeo, and Shell Smash Cloyster also appreciate Kingdra's wallbreaking abilities, while they deal with Pokemon like Chansey, Ferrothorn, Jellicent, and Toxapex, which are otherwise hard for Kingdra to deal with.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Porygon2 is a great physically defensive option available to Normal teams with the ability to utilize Teleport and check Dragon Dance Dragapult, Mimikyu, and Jirachi, which would all otherwise prove very threatening for Normal. Recover provides Porygon2 with a reliable form of healing for it to continually switch into attacks from Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Excadrill and Mimikyu. Foul Play acts both as a countermeasure for Pokemon like Scizor and Azumarill that would otherwise use Porygon2 as setup bait and as an attacking move to hit other powerful physical threats like Alolan Marowak and Excadrill. Ice Beam gives Porygon2 good coverage to deal with Dragon threats like Hydreigon and Noivern more easily as well as certain other offensive threats like Diggersby and Hawlucha. Toxic allows Porygon2 to wear down defensive Pokemon like Mandibuzz and Gastrodon that may otherwise attempt to switch in. Teleport is another option to be considered, as it allows Porygon2 to bring in frail offensive Normal-type threats like Diggersby, Heliolisk, and Indeedee-M safely and create momentum. Discharge can be an option to run over Toxic as good coverage for hitting Flying- and Water-type threats like Corviknight and Pelipper with a sizable chance to paralyze notable threats for Normal teams such as Calm Mind Keldeo and Bulk Up Urshifu-R, which would otherwise use Porygon2 as setup fodder. Trace is generally the preferred ability due to the potential of copying abilities like Natural Cure from Chansey, Regenerator from Toxapex and Amoonguss, and Intimidate from Krookodile, all of which increase Porygon2's survivability. Maximum investment in HP and Defense with a Bold nature is used to have Porygon2 perform its best as a physical wall against threats like Excadrill and Scizor.

Most if not all Pokemon on Normal appreciate Porygon2's ability to deal with physical threats. Blissey in particular forms an excellent defensive core with Porygon2 due to being especially weak to offensive physical threats. Porygon2 in return appreciates Blissey's role as a special wall to help deal with strong special threats that itself cannot hold off like Kingdra in rain and Volcarona. If Porygon2 is running Teleport, frail offensive threats like Diggersby and Indeedee-M appreciate its ability to bring them in safely without leaving them open to attacks and status moves. Braviary helps Porygon2 deal with hard-hitting threats that have Fighting-type coverage like Heracross and Rillaboom. Porygon2 is especially susceptible to all forms of entry hazards, particularly Toxic Spikes, due to their ability to quickly wear down Porygon2 and reduce its ability of switching into attacks reliably. As a result, Porygon2 along with the entire Normal team appreciates Braviary's ability of keeping hazards off through the use of Defog. Ditto makes for a good partner due to its ability to punish offensive setup sweepers that may use Porygon2 as setup fodder like Belly Drum Azumarill, Swords Dance Excadrill, and Bulk Up Urshifu-S. Ditto and Porygon2 also work well together due to their ability to PP stall Poison and Water teams by copying Regenerator from Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss. Heliolisk provides Porygon2 with an easier time against Water due to its great ability in Dry Skin for absorbing powerful Water-type attacks from wallbreakers like Dracovish. Bewear appreciates Porygon2's ability to mitigate its low Speed by paralyzing faster Pokemon like Hydreigon and Kyurem with Discharge. Porygon2 in return gains a partner to help deal with Steel- types like Corviknight and Ferrothorn that it would otherwise have a hard time dealing with.

Blissey.overview:
Normal

Blissey's amazing bulk, role of status absorber thanks to Natural Cure, and utility moves such as Stealth Rock and Soft-Boiled in conjunction with Heavy-Duty Boots all make it one of Monotype's best walls. Teleport makes Blissey one of the best defensive pivots in the metagame and synergizes well with strong wallbreakers like Diggersby. Blissey forms one of the most potent defensive cores in Monotype with Braviary and Porygon2. However, due to Blissey's near nonexistent offensive presence, it is extremely susceptible to offensive setup users like Dragapult and Bisharp. Stallbreakers also easily take advantage of it and Knock Off users like Mew severely threaten it. Blissey also fails to successfully hold its own against other defensive Pokemon like Slowbro and Toxapex.
Blissey.comments:
Other Options

Normal

Blissey can opt to run Toxic, Thunder Wave, or Heal Bell in lieu of Stealth Rock. However, its teammates generally appreciate Stealth Rock more.

Checks and Counters

Normal

Setup Sweepers: Due to Blissey's passivity, setup sweepers, especially ones with reliable recovery such as Dragapult and Scizor, comfortably set up on it.

Stallbreakers: As Blissey heavily relies on its utility moves, stallbreakers such as Mew, Zarude, and Mandibuzz can completely shut it down with Taunt, even preventing it from bringing in a teammate with Teleport.

Wallbreakers: While Blissey's amazing bulk allows it to comfortably deal with a majority of both physical and special threats, powerful wallbreakers like Choice Band Victini, Galarian Darmanitan, and Crawdaunt have little to no trouble breaking through it.

sets.name: Defensive (Normal)
sets.description:
Stealth Rock eases the path for Blissey's offensive teammates while also heavily chipping down threats like Galarian Darmanitan and Choice Band Victini. Seismic Toss prevents Blissey from being totally passive, allowing it to deal notable damage to offensive Pokemon like Tapu Koko and Taunt users such as Mew. Soft-Boiled provides reliable recovery, allowing Blissey to act as a reliable wall against foes like Hydreigon and Nidoking throughout the game. Teleport makes it a great defensive pivot, safely bringing in its offensive teammates like Diggersby and Heliolisk.

All of Blissey's teammates appreciate its ability to absorb status conditions while safely bringing them into the field with Teleport. Porygon2 and Braviary form a potent defensive core with Blissey. Porygon2 can reliably switch into physical attacks from the likes of Landorus-T while also forming a great Teleport core with Blissey, while Braviary provides Defog support for the team and a neutrality to Fighting-type attacks, switching in against foes such as Choice Scarf Heracross. Diggersby is a great wallbreaker, taking care of opposing walls like Ferrothorn and Toxapex that Blissey fails to do much against, while Heliolisk aids greatly in the Water- and Flying-type matchups. Obstagoon provides a Psychic immunity while also threatening Ghost-type Pokemon like Blacephalon and Aegislash, which wall Blissey completely. Ditto deals with setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Aegislash that get the better of Blissey's passivity. Indeedee aids greatly in the Fighting-type matchup and provides a great special wallbreaker for Normal-type teams.

Suicune.overview:
Water

Sporting great defensive stats, amazing defensive typing, and decent natural Speed, Suicune is able to wall and stall many Pokemon in Monotype such as Slowking and Tapu Lele. Thanks to its ability in Pressure, Calm Mind, and its natural bulk, Suicune can stall out menacing walls such as Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Toxapex one-on-one. It is also able to effectively stall out menacing attacks like Tapu Bulu's Horn Leech with Pressure. Due to its lack of reliable recovery, Suicune is extremely vulnerable to entry hazards, status, and other chip damage leaving it unable to reliably switch into attacks. In addition, having Scald as its only offensive move makes it vulnerable to Water-immune Pokemon such as Gastrodon and Mantine. Furthermore, Suicune's heavy reliance on Leftovers makes it extremely vulnerable to Knock Off.
Suicune.comments:
Other Options

Water

Rest and Sleep Talk can be used over Protect + Substitute in order to fully recover HP, but that leaves Suicune as setup bait and relies on RNG to select the ideal moves. This set also makes Suicune worse at PP stalling.

Checks and Counters

Water

Water-types: Specially defensive Water-type Pokemon easily wall Scald and force Suicune to switch. Toxapex is particularly a threat due to its access to Haze and reliable recovery.

Electric-types: Pokemon such as Regieleki and Alolan Raichu can spam Thunderbolt and Rising Voltage against Suicune, but it can threaten them from behind a Substitute, especially if it has used Calm Mind.

Chip Damage: Any chip damage, like from damaging entry hazards and status conditions, reduces Suicune's ability to wall its foes. Toxic Spikes deserves a special mention, as it automatically puts Suicune on a timer.

Grass-types: Grass-types resisting Scald makes them extremely hard to break past. Tapu Bulu deserves a special mention for its ability to set up a Substitute and proceed to use Suicune as setup fodder. Rillaboom's Grassy Glide will not only OHKO Suicune but decimate any Water team. However, both Rillaboom and Tapu Bulu fear Scald burns, making opponents reluctant to switch them in.

Haze Users and Phazing: Moves such as Haze and Whirlwind make it difficult for Suicune to set up for a late-game sweep.

Stallbreakers: Common Taunt users like Cobalion and Keldeo can lock Suicune into Scald, which is only threatening after it has used Calm Mind. Suicune is also vulnerable to Encore, which allows opposing physical attackers to come in and revenge kill it without the risk of being burned by Scald.

Water-immune Pokemon: Due to Scald being its only offensive move, Suicune is unable to damage Water-immune pokemon such as Cradily and Mantine. However, Suicune is able to annoy them through Pressure stalling.

sets.name: Calm Mind + Substitute (Water)
sets.description:
Calm Mind allows Suicune to both sweep and take on special attackers like Tornadus-T while being able to fire back with Scald; Scald allows Suicune to spread burns, which threaten opposing physical attackers such as Dragonite and Scizor coming in. Protect adds passive recovery via Leftovers and works with Substitute and Pressure to PP stall foes; Protect also allows Suicune to scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Rillaboom, Tapu Lele, and Latios. Substitute can also be used to block status conditions such as poison and burn that would nullify Suicune's passive recovery and therefore prevent it from effectively PP stalling. It can create a Substitute for free on Pokemon like defensive Celesteela. Suicune's HP investment allows it to form a Substitute with 101 HP, which doesn't break after one Night Shade or Seismic Toss from Galarian Corsola or Blissey.

Toxapex is able to provide Toxic Spikes support, which helps Suicune stall out its foes. In addition, it can stop setup sweepers like Bisharp with Haze. Swampert provides an Electric immunity to the team and phazes setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Dragapult with Roar. Furthermore, Swampert can set Stealth Rock, which helps Suicune wear down opposing teams. Urshifu-R is good to break past many potential checks to Suicune, such as Water-immune Pokemon such as Cradily, Seismitoad, and Mantine, with Close Combat and Thunder Punch. Tapu Fini provides a Dragon immunity while also setting up Misty Terrain, which prevents Suicune from becoming statused, and threatening Suicune's Dragon-type checks like Latios and Hydreigon. In turn, Suicune can assist Tapu Fini by spreading burns and PP stalling its checks such as Skuntank. Choice Scarf Tapu Fini also helps to weaken foes with Trick and Knock Off. Mantine not only removes hazards like Toxic Spikes, but also offers a Ground immunity. In addition, it provides a key neutrality to Grass. Mantine also has Haze to stifle setup Pokemon like Belly Drum Azumarill and Volcarona.
