Slowking assists Suicune and the team by filling the role of a specially defensive pivot, bringing in Suicune with ease and countering Pokemon it struggles against such as Toxapex and Toxicroak. Teammates with Heal Bell like Vaporeon help with Suicune's vulnerability to status chip damage.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Dark)
sets.description:
With its respectable bulk, Tyranitar is the primary Stealth Rock user for Dark-type teams. The combination of Fire Blast and Stone Edge deals with most lead Pokemon, such as Ferrothorn, Xatu, and Ribombee. Thunder Wave can be used to cripple some of the problematic setup sweepers that can easily exploit Tyranitar, such as Hawlucha and Gyarados, on the switch. A specially defensive EV spread along with Sand Stream is used to benefit from Tyranitar's special bulk as much as possible against foes like Charizard and Togekiss. Sand Stream can be also used as a tool to reset opposing weathers, giving Dark-type teams some space in unfavorable matchups such as against rain Water.

Offensive Dark-type Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl and Hydreigon appreciate the presence of Tyranitar, as its Stealth Rock paired with sand allows them to break the opposing team more easily. Hydreigon also benefits heavily from Tyranitar's Thunder Wave, which allows it to outspeed some of the fastest Pokemon in the metagame such as Dragapult and Hawlucha. Sableye and Mandibuzz make good defensive partners to Tyranitar with their capability of handling Bug- and Fighting-type moves. Mandibuzz can also take on Ground-type attacks for Tyranitar.

sets.name: Dragon Dance (Dark)
sets.description:
Tyranitar can become a powerful setup sweeper for Dark teams thanks to its access to Dragon Dance and amazing coverage options, allowing it to threaten types such as Fire, Electric, and Poison. Stone Edge breaks past Pokemon such as Blissey, Pelipper, and Mandibuzz. Earthquake is mainly used for Toxapex and Steel-types like Aegislash, Heatproof Bronzong, and Klefki. Heavy Slam deals with Fairy-types like Hatterene and Galarian Weezing, while Fire Punch is particularly useful to hit Ferrothorn reliably. Substitute is also an option to set up more easily on weaker Pokemon like Torkoal, Toxapex, and Galarian Weezing, and Leftovers is used along with it to gain passive recovery. Lum Berry prevents Tyranitar from being crippled by the likes of Toxapex, Slowking, and Salazzle. Tyranitar should use its good bulk paired with Sand Stream to set up easily on special attackers like Dragalge and Rotom-H as well as passive Pokemon like Amoonguss. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows it to outspeed Alolan Ninetales and Choice Specs Gengar after a Dragon Dance boost.

Dragon Dance Tyranitar primarily fits on hyper offense teams and can take on threats like Togekiss and Volcarona, which its teammates appreciate. Krookodile is the premier option for setting Stealth Rock while also providing utility in Knock Off and Taunt to dismantle threats like Porygon2, Gastrodon, and Corviknight. Taunt can also prevent entry hazards from slower leads such as Skarmory, which helps Tyranitar stay healthy. Hydreigon can weaken physically defensive Pokemon like Bewear, Corviknight, and Hippowdon for Tyranitar, making it an important wallbreaker. Mandibuzz can use Defog to get rid of hazards like Sticky Web and Toxic Spikes, which would otherwise make Tyranitar easier to revenge kill. It also deals with Fighting- and Ground-types like Choice Scarf Cobalion, Excadrill, and Hawlucha while providing U-turn support. Urshifu-S can threaten Steel teams for Tyranitar with its powerful STAB move combination and pick off faster threats such as Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Jirachi with Sucker Punch. Grimmsnarl provides useful dual screens for Tyranitar, which allows it to set up on Pokemon like Charizard and Kyurem more safely throughout the match. Drapion and Bisharp are able to help against problematic Fairy-types like Primarina, Grimmsnarl, Galarian Weezing, and Mimikyu so Tyranitar can forego Heavy Slam. Additionally, Drapion can spread status with Toxic Spikes, which is useful for preventing Electric teams from switching in freely.

sets.name: Nasty Plot (Grass)
sets.description:
Celebi is a great choice for Grass teams due to its bulk, access to Nasty Plot, and Psychic typing, allowing it to threaten Poison- and Fighting-types that give its teammates trouble like Toxapex and Cobalion. Nasty Plot turns Celebi into a dangerous sweeper, that can dismantle troubling matchups such as Poison and Steel. Giga Drain allows it to have passive recovery and mitigates Life Orb's recoil damage. Psychic helps greatly in the Poison- and the Fighting-type matchup, as Celebi can take care of Toxapex and Kommo-o with it. Earth Power is used to hit most Steel- and Poison-types such as Excadrill and Skuntank. Weather Ball can be used over Earth Power on sun teams to hit Corviknight and Ferrothorn when sun is active. Celebi should try to come in on passive attacks such as Toxapex's Scald, on a predicted switch, via U-turn, or after a teammate faints. Nasty Plot should be used on Pokemon it can threaten out such as Toxapex and Keldeo. Having 252 Special Attack EVs and Life Orb allows Celebi to be as powerful as possible, and 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature allow it to outpace Lucario and Speed tie with Jirachi.

Celebi loves Stealth Rock support from Ferrothorn, as it makes it easier for Celebi to sweep mid- to late-game and can swap into faster Poison-type Pokemon like Gengar. Celebi also appreciates Ferrothorn's Steel typing to take physical attacks or Ice-type attacks from Pokemon like Mamoswine and Alolan Ninetales. Appletun is another key member that forms a defensive core with Ferrothorn and can come in on Fire-type attacks thanks to its Dragon typing and Thick Fat. Choice Scarf Virizion provides great speed control and can OHKO Alolan Ninetales with Smart Strike, use its Fighting-type STAB moves greatly in the Dark-type matchup to take care of Hydreigon and Bisharp, and handle Choice Scarf Charizard with Stone Edge. Virizion can also serve on sun teams as a secondary Sunny Day setter if Whimsicott is eliminated. Rotom-C is another good teammate to help take care of Flying-types such as Togekiss and can use Nasty Plot, Substitute, and Dark Pulse to greatly help out in the Ghost-type matchup. Whimsicott is another good member, especially if Celebi is running Weather Ball, thanks to its Prankster-boosted Sunny Day, allowing Celebi to sweep Steel teams with Weather Ball. Whimsicott is also able to switch into Dragon-type attacks for Celebi and hit back with Moonblast. Shiftry is good to pair with Celebi because it helps greatly with the Psychic- and Ghost-type matchup, using its STAB attacks to take care of troubling Pokemon like Indeedee and Chandelure. In return, Celebi takes care of threats to Shiftry such as Lucario and Toxapex. Venusaur is a nice partner because it can help greatly with Fairy-types such as Togekiss as well as threats to Celebi like Bisharp and Aegislash with Weather Ball when sun is active.

Swampert.overview:
Water

Providing a key immunity to Electric-type moves as well as walling Pokemon such as Regieleki, defensive Zapdos, and Zeraora, Swampert is a good addition to any Water team. In addition, Swampert has access to a wide variety of utility moves, including Stealth Rock and Roar. It is also able to take hits in order to reliably set Stealth Rock multiple times during a battle. Its Water / Ground typing may turn out to be its eventual downfall, as Swampert is 4x weak to Grass-type attacks from Rillaboom, Tapu Koko, and Thundurus-T. Swampert suffers from constantly tanking hits from foes due to having no reliable recovery and therefore has little longevity. This prevents it from switching in and out of battle constantly, making Defog users a nuisance. Swampert can generate momentum with Flip Turn, preventing it from becoming passive.
Swampert.comments:
Other Options

Water

A set with Rindo Berry and Mirror Coat is able to catch threats such as Alolan Raichu, Tapu Koko, and Thundurus-T off guard. However, it severely reduces Swampert's HP, making it harder to bring it onto the field. Furthermore, this set can be scouted for with any chip damage. Toxic can be run over Roar in order to put bulkier walls such as Mantine and Mandibuzz on a timer; however, this prevents Swampert from phazing setup sweepers such as Hydreigon.

Checks and Counters

Water

Bulky Water-types: Pokemon such as Mantine and Rotom-W are immune or resistant to both of Swampert's offensive moves, in addition to having the ability to get rid of Stealth Rock via Defog. Mantine is particularly dangerous, as Swampert is also unable to use Flip Turn against it due to its Water Absorb ability.

Physical Walls: Bulky foes such as Celesteela and Mandibuzz can Toxic stall Swampert while being immune to Earthquake.

Grass-types: Due to having a 4x weakness to the type, Grass-type coverage can easily break past Swampert.

Knock Off: Knock Off can be used on Swampert to remove Leftovers, meaning it has no way to reliably recover HP. This in turn diminishes Swampert's ability to act as wall somewhat effectively and prevents it from consistently being able to set up Stealth Rock multiple times during a battle.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Zapdos, Choice Specs Keldeo, and Nidoking pose an immense threat to Swampert due to its lack of reliable recovery.

Status: Like most walls, status conditions such as burn and poison severely hinder Swampert's ability to wall its foes.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Swampert is able to set Stealth Rock in order to reduce the longevity of Pokemon that do not run Heavy-Duty Boots such as Choice Specs Zapdos. Earthquake is used to prevent Swampert from being strictly passive, allowing it to hit Electric- and Poison-types like Tapu Koko, Zeraora, and Toxapex. Roar not only takes advantage of the aforementioned Stealth Rock, but it allows Swampert to phaze setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Dragonite, preventing it from becoming setup fodder. Flip Turn takes advantage of Swampert's little Speed investment to allow the player to gain momentum by having switch advantage. Swampert's EVs allow it to survive a Grass Knot from Choice Specs Tapu Koko and KO it back with Earthquake after Stealth Rock damage.

Almost all Water-type Pokemon benefit from the presence of Swampert on the team, as it is able to shield the rest of the team from Electric-type moves such as Rising Voltage and Thunderbolt, as well as set Stealth Rock. Notable mentions of Pokemon that benefit from Swampert being on a team are Pelipper and Mantine, as they both have a 4x weakness to Electric-type moves. Pelipper and Mantine can also switch into Ground-type moves to prevent Swampert from taking unnecessary damage. Pelipper can set rain for Swift Swim teammates that Swampert can pivot in via Flip Turn, and Mantine can use Defog for its teammates. Due to the aforementioned immunity, Swampert and Toxapex form a defensive backbone together, with Toxapex being able to take on physical attackers for Swampert such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Dragonite. Toxapex can also absorb Toxic Spikes and Toxic for Swampert. Swampert assists wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Keldeo and Barraskewda. These wallbreakers are able to take care of walls such as Blissey, Porygon2, and Skarmory, which Swampert struggles against due to its passive nature. Choice Specs Keldeo especially is an amazing teammate for Swampert, as Flip Turn can bring it in to obtain KOs on both physical and special walls such as Blissey, Ferrothorn, and Celesteela. Choice Scarf Urshifu-R heavily benefits from the presence of Swampert, as it not only provides an aforementioned immunity to Electric but a special wall to take the special hits that Urshifu-R cannot. In turn, Urshifu-R can handle Dark- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Ferrothorn for Swampert, as well as being able to revenge kill threats such as Tapu Koko and Zeraora. Tapu Fini prevents Swampert from being statused and can help Swampert avoid entry hazard damage with Defog. Tapu Fini also deals with Dragon-types that can wall Swampert such as Hydreigon, Kyurem, and Latios. Slowking also appreciates the aforementioned immunity as well, and Swampert appreciates a switch-in for certain special attackers such as Tapu Lele. Suicune is an excellent partner for Swampert due to its ability to stall out many bulkier Pokemon that Swampert would otherwise be unable to hit such as Celesteela. Slowking can form a pivoting core with Swampert, bringing in teammates like Barraskewda safely and then having them wreak havoc.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Grass)
sets.description:
Shiftry has decent Attack and fairly decent Speed with incredible wallbreaking potential thanks to Swords Dance, Black Glasses, and Dark-type STAB moves and is strictly seen on Sunny Day variant Grass teams. Shiftry is great for Psychic- and Ghost-type matchups and beats common threats such as Dragapult and Indeedee. Substitute is useful for avoiding moves like Will-O-Wisp, Toxic, and Strength Sap from Pokemon such as Galarian Corsola, Mew, and Toxapex; with Substitute up, Shiftry can get a free Swords Dance and wall break. The combination of Sucker Punch and Substitute makes it difficult for revenge kills from Pokemon like Trace Gardevoir or Gengar to happen. Chlorophyll doubles its Speed, making Shiftry a fiercer wallbreaker to eliminate. Knock Off is useful for inflicting massive damage and removing the item of anything that tries to switch in against it, while Sucker Punch is useful for KOing faster sweepers such as Dragapult and Gengar. Maximum Speed investment allows Shiftry to outspeed Choice Scarf Charizard and Salazzle in sun, and maximum Attack investment with an Adamant nature permits Shiftry to reach its full wallbreaking potential.

Whimsicott and Virizion are viable options to set up Sunny Day, allowing Shiftry to outspeed Pokemon such as Mew and Jirachi because of Chlorophyll. Whimsicott is a better Sunny Day setter that helps with Dragon-, Dark-, and Fighting-types thanks to Moonblast; Choice Scarf Virizion is useful for outspeeding threats like Alolan Ninetales, Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, and Choice Scarf Charizard and has access to Smart Strike, Stone Edge, and Close Combat, which is useful for the Ice-type matchup. Appletun is one of the only Grass-types that can properly tank Fire-type attacks from Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Dragapult. Venusaur is another Pokemon that takes advantage of sun and can use Life Orb and Growth or Choice Specs and helps in the Fairy- and Steel-type matchup because of Weather Ball and Sludge Bomb. Ferrothorn is one of the best defensive utilities that has access to entry hazards such as Stealth Rock and Spikes; it is useful for tanking attacks from offensive Pokemon like Weavile and Cloyster and is very crucial for the Ice-type matchup. Rotom-C cripples Pokemon with Choice Scarf and Trick, which is incredibly useful for against Pokemon such as Corviknight, Mew, and Toxapex. Finally, Celebi gets Stealth Rock, which allows Ferrothorn to run Spikes, and has a number of coverage moves such as Psychic and Earth Power which helps fend off Poison- and Fighting-type Pokemon better.

sets.name: Choice Attacker (Water)
sets.description:
Pelipper is an invaluable asset for offensive Water teams due to its ability to support its teammates with rain. In addition, Pelipper has access to a powerful STAB Hurricane, making it one of the primary ways the type is able to deal with Grass-types. With a Choice Scarf, Pelipper can act as a revenge killer and threaten Pokemon like Kommo-o, Hawlucha, and Excadrill. A Choice Specs set will instead turn Pelipper into a wallbreaker focused on weakening types like Grass and Flying. U-turn is necessary so Pelipper can pivot into its teammates, and Ice Beam is able to threaten Dragon-types like Hydreigon more effectively. Maximum Speed and Special Attack investment allows Pelipper to emphasize its offensive capabilities, with a Timid nature notably allowing Pelipper to outspeed Hawlucha with a Choice Scarf and Tyranitar without it.

Pelipper primarily enables Swift Swim sweepeers such as Seismitoad and Barraskewda to become massive offensive threats. Its rain can also help other offensive Pokemon on Water such as Crawdaunt and Gyarados. Pelipper often falls short against Electric-types like Rotom-W, meaning that an Electric-immune Pokemon like Seismitoad is essential. Secondary checks to Grass-types are also appreciated, since Pelipper will often be worn down easily if it is the sole check to them; Toxapex and Gyarados can fill this role nicely.

sets.name: Revenge Killer (Fairy)
sets.description:
Thanks to its ability Trace, Gardevoir is specifically used to revenge kill common threatening weather sweepers for Fairy-type teams. With coverage moves like Energy Ball and Focus Blast, Gardevoir is able to revenge kill threats like Seismitoad, Drednaw, Barraskewda, and Excadrill against Water- and Ground-type teams, respectively. Additionally, Gardevoir helps in beating Poison-type Pokemon such as Toxtricity and Gengar, which can be pain otherwise for Fairy-type teams. Gardevoir has low bulk, so it should be brought in via a free switch after a Pokemon has fainted to revenge kill the foe or through aggressive double switching to threaten opposing Pokemon. The Speed EVs along with a Choice Scarf and Trace make it possible to outspeed the aforementioned weather sweepers.

Slower Pokemon such as Nasty Plot Togekiss and Mimikyu benefit from Gardevoir's ability to revenge kill faster Pokemon like Salazzle and weather sweepers of Water- and Ground-type teams. Wallbreakers like Bulk Up Grimmsnarl appreciate Gardevoir as a cleaner. Due to its middling Speed stat, faster revenge killers can outspeed and threaten to beat it, hence Pokemon like Ribombee can provide Sticky Web support to allow Gardevoir to outspeed opposing Pokemon more readily.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Psychic)
sets.description:
Gardevoir is a fantastic Choice Scarf user for Psychic teams thanks to its Fairy typing and access to Moonblast, which allows it to revenge kill otherwise troublesome Dark-types. It is also a fantastic check to weather-focused types such as Water and Ground, as it can easily dispatch of their respective weather sweepers, such as Barraskewda and Excadrill, thanks to Trace and good coverage in Energy Ball and Focus Blast. Choice Scarf is a necessity to revenge kill these sweepers after their ability has been copied. Psychic is a great STAB option that prevents Gardevoir from being walled by Poison-types like Toxapex, while Healing Wish can be used late-game to allow a weakened teammate to clean up. Maximum Special Attack and Speed investment maximizes Gardevoir's offensive capabilities, as it does not need to invest in bulk.

Every Pokemon on Psychic appreciates Gardevoir's ability to manage Dark-types, as they are a large threat to the type. Furthermore, frailer offensive threats such as Indeedee and Gallade greatly value Gardevoir's ability to keep weather sweepers in check. Gardevoir is walled by bulky Steel-types such as Aegislash and Corviknight, making Pokemon that can wear them down, such as Hatterene, good partners. Furthermore, entry hazard support from the likes of Bronzong and Mew makes cleaning with Gardevoir late-game much easier, as Gardevoir often falls short of KOing opposing Pokemon without sufficient chip damage.

sets.name: Stallbreaker (Dark)
sets.description:
Sableye acts as a stallbreaker for Dark teams with its combination of Prankster and Taunt, being able to shut down annoying threats like Bulk Up Corviknight, hazard setters like Ferrothorn, and defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, while also having reliable recovery in Recover. It can also act as a Fighting-type check with its good typing in Ghost / Dark, giving it a immunity to this type while also being immune to Rapid Spin. It can also cripple physical attackers that threaten Dark teams such as Mamoswine with Will-O-Wisp. Using Knock Off it can get rid of important items such as Black Sludge and Leftovers from certain Pokemon, helping it stallbreak more efficiently. Sableye runs a fully specially defensive spread to increase its overall bulk, being able to take hits better from Pokemon as Duraludon and Gengar because it already fights physical attackers decently through burning them. However, due to its mediocre defensive stats, Sableye can't switch into powerful attacks such as Dracovish's Fishious Rend.

Sableye pairs well with Tyranitar and Mandibuzz, covering for Sableye's average defenses and taking care of powerful attackers such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Bisharp respectively, forming a good defensive core. Mandibuzz can Defog hazards away so Sableye can enter more comfortably onto the field. Also, a teammate such as Toxic Spikes Drapion helps it by spreading status, but note that Sableye would then not be able to burn Pokemon like Mamoswine when they are already poisoned. Wallbreakers such as Hydreigon, Bisharp, and Grimmsnarl are also good teammates for Sableye, being able to clean more easily with Sableye preventing hazards being set and wearing down the enemy team. Bisharp and Drapion also help in the Fairy matchup, which is a matchup problematic for Dark. Grimmsnarl also helps Sableye versus other Dark teams due to Dark-type's immunity to Prankster.

sets.name: Stallbreaker (Ghost)
sets.description:
Sableye's main merit on Ghost teams comes from its access to Prankster, along with good utility moves like Taunt and Will-O-Wisp, making it an exceptional stallbreaker. This, along with reliable recovery in Recover, makes it hard to beat for many teams alike. Generally, Taunt should be used to block setup, recovery, entry hazards, and status, and should be used in conjunction with Will-O-Wisp and Knock Off to break down many different Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Toxapex, Corviknight, and more. Be aware that Prankster Will-O-Wisp is especially useful for crippling faster offensive threats that Ghost teams hate dealing with such as Excadrill, Barraskewda, and Dracozolt. Maximum HP and Special Defense investment ensures Sableye is as specially bulky as possible, and it can cripple physical attackers with Will-O-Wisp just fine.

The entire Ghost team appreciates Sableye's ability to block entry hazard setters from setting entry hazards using Taunt, seeing as Ghost teams typically do not carry entry hazard control. Galarian Corsola aids Sableye defensively, as it is also able to cripple Pokemon with Will-O-Wisp and take on more threatening wallbreakers like Mamoswine, Diggersby and Excadrill more comfortably with its sturdy bulk. Offensive Ghost-type Pokemon like Gengar, Polteageist, Mimikyu, Dragapult, and Aegislash appreciate Sableye's ability to stallbreak and soften up the opposition, making it easier for them to sweep.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Torkoal is an amazing utility Pokemon on Fire because of its role compression, as it has Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, combined with its ability to set sun using Drought and its good Defense stat. Yawn prevents Torkoal from being set up on and is crucial in order to force Pokemon out and get off a last minute Rapid Spin. Lava Plume is the only attack on the set and is used to spread burns. Torkoal should generally be sent out early in order to set sun and Stealth Rock up for its other teammates. It should be preserved throughout the match in order to set sun and remove hazards constantly. Maximum HP and Defense EVs along with a Bold nature allow Torkoal to take hits from Pokemon like Tyranitar and Excadrill with more ease.

Pokemon like Cinderace and Rotom-H appreciate Torkoal's hazard removal, while the entire team benefits from the sun Torkoal sets. Pokemon like Charizard and Cinderace in particular appreciate Torkoal's Yawn in order to find more opportunities to break down the opposition. In return, Torkoal appreciates these same Pokemon, as they can revenge kill faster Pokemon like Hydreigon and Duraludon that threaten Torkoal.

sets.name: Choice Band (Water)
sets.description:
Choice Band combined with Adaptability makes Crawdaunt an insanely powerful wallbreaker. Knock Off is its primary STAB move and provides useful utility in removing the foe's item. Close Combat hits Ferrothorn for more damage. Aqua Jet provides priority to make up for Crawdaunt's low Speed. Crawdaunt should be used to break holes early-game and pave the way for its teammates to win the game. Its Speed and bulk are pretty low, so it should generally be brought in on slower Pokemon and fire off its powerful attacks. Bringing Crawdaunt in via double switching or pivot moves is an effective way of applying pressure on the opponent, since very few Pokemon appreciate switching in on it. Crawdaunt can even clean up on its own with Aqua Jet if the opposing team has been weakened enough.

Pelipper can set up rain to boost Crawdaunt's Crabhammer and Aqua Jet. It can also pivot with U-turn to give Crawdaunt safe switches into the field. Rotom-W can pivot as well with Volt Switch and can also cripple the opposing Pokemon with Thunder Wave. Toxapex is an amazing teammate because it covers many of Crawdaunt's weaknesses and is also a great pivot in general thanks to its amazing bulk and Regenerator. In addition, it can set up Toxic Spikes to cripple the opposing team for Crawdaunt. Seismitoad is immune to Electric-type attacks that threaten Crawdaunt and can set up Stealth Rock to chip away at the opposing team. Araquanid has access to Sticky Web to slow down the opposing team, making Crawdaunt even more threatening to deal with. Gyarados works well as a teammate because it can take advantage of Crawdaunt's wallbreaking and sweep late-game.

sets.name: Choice Band (Dark)
sets.description:
With a high base Attack stat in conjunction with a phenomenal ability in Adaptability, Choice Band Crawdaunt serves as a hard-hitting wallbreaker for Dark teams. Knock Off is Crawdaunt's most powerful and most spammable Dark-type STAB move, allowing it to remove items from targets. Crabhammer is the strongest Water-type STAB move backed by Adaptability, cleanly OHKOing the likes of physically defensive Hippowdon and 2HKOing physically defensive Mandibuzz and defensive Corviknight. Aqua Jet makes up for Crawdaunt's low Speed and additionally allows it to pick off weakened or frail Pokemon such as Alolan Raichu, Gardevoir, Galarian Darmanitan, and Zeraora. Close Combat serves as a stronger means of hitting Ferrothorn as well as threatens Normal teams, as no Normal-type can switch into it. Alternatively, Crunch allows Crawdaunt to maintain the 2HKO on an itemless Toxapex. Crawdaunt should be brought into the battle to wallbreak with pivoting moves such as U-turn or through double switches, as it cannot switch into attacks due to its lackluster bulk. Maximum Attack investment in conjunction with an Adamant nature while holding a Choice Band allows Crawdaunt to hit as hard as possible. Maximum Speed investment allows Crawdaunt to outspeed defensive Rotom-W and defensive Mandibuzz.

Tyranitar is able to provide Stealth Rock support, which wears the opposing team down and allows Crawdaunt to wallbreak more easily. Tyranitar can also cripple threats such as Mew, Gardevoir, and Indeedee-M with Thunder Wave, allowing Crawdaunt to outspeed them and making up for its lackluster Speed tier. Mandibuzz can switch into Pokemon such as Flygon, Virizion, and Excadrill that threaten Crawdaunt greatly, Defog away entry hazards such as Toxic Spikes and Sticky Web that hinder Crawdaunt, and allow Crawdaunt to safely get into the battle with U-turn. Weavile and Bisharp appreciate Crawdaunt's wallbreaking abilities, as they all share similar checks. Weavile is able to beat Dragon-types such as Kommo-o and Noivern, while Bisharp is able to defeat Fairy-types such as Galarian Weezing and Hatterene. Additionally, Crawdaunt is able to wallbreak and punch holes through teams early-game, allowing Bisharp to sweep late-game. Dual screens Grimmsnarl makes up for Crawdaunt's poor bulk, allowing it to take hits more easily, while Bulk Up Grimmsnarl appreciates Crawdaunt's wallbreaking capabilities weakening Pokemon like Toxapex and allowing it to sweep more easily. Drapion is able to threaten Fairy-types such as Primarina, Togekiss, and Whimsicott, which all threaten Crawdaunt, in addition to providing Toxic Spikes support for Crawdaunt to wallbreak more easily. Incineroar is able to switch into Grass- and Fairy-type attacks and can provide Crawdaunt with a slow U-turn to enter the battle safely.

Cradily.overview:
Grass

Cradily is a great support option for Grass teams because of its utility options in Stealth Rock and Toxic, part-Rock typing that provides neutrality to Flying- and Fire-type attacks, and ability in Storm Drain to absorb Water-type attacks. Its part-Rock typing in conjunction with its high Special Defense and reliable recovery betters its ability to take on special attackers like Volcarona, Zapdos, and Tornadus-T. It forms a great defensive core with Amoonguss and Ferrothorn, with all covering each others' weaknesses fairly well. However, Cradily's typing leaves it susceptible to threats like Fighting-, Steel-, and Ice-types like Terrakion, Scizor, Galarian Darmanitan, and Glastrier. Its poor offensive stats give setup sweepers like Excadrill, Rillaboom, and Dragapult opportunities to set up with ease.
Cradily.comments:
Other Options

Grass

Earthquake is an option over Toxic to hit Poison- and Steel-types like Dragalge, Nidoking, Heatran, and Magnezone, but be aware of Rillaboom's Grassy Terrain being active. Heavy-Duty Boots is another effective way to keep Cradily healthy, since Grass normally doesn't run entry hazard removal.

Checks and Counters

Grass

Poison-types: Poison-types like Galarian Weezing and Toxapex are immune to Toxic and aren't bothered by Cradily's Rock Blast. They can also hinder its recovery with Will-O-Wisp or Toxic.

Status: Cradily should be cautious of status, particularly Toxic and burns, because the former limits it as a reliable defensive switch-in and the latter halves the damage of Rock Blast.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Celesteela, Excadrill, and Aegislash can easily take Rock Blast repeatedly, are immune to Toxic, and can KO Cradily with their Steel-type attacks. Setup sweepers like Bisharp and Scizor can additionally set up. However, Earthquake can deal with Pokemon like Heatran and Magnezone.

Wallbreakers: Physical wallbreakers like Choice Band Zeraora and Choice Band Rillaboom can OHKO Cradily with their STAB attacks or super effective coverage moves, while special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Hydreigon can heavily dent Cradily.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Grass)
sets.description:
Rock Blast hits Flying-, Ice-, Bug-, and Fire-types like Zapdos, Alolan Ninetales, Araquanid, and Volcarona and helps with Pokemon that commonly set up Substitute like Galarian Moltres, Hydreigon, and Kyurem. Kyurem, in particular, can stall out other Rock-type STAB moves due to Pressure. Toxic allows Cradily to cripple potential switch-ins, bulkier Pokemon like Hippowdon, Mandibuzz, and Porygon2 that can recover off damage from Rock Blast, and setup sweepers like Hydreigon that may try using it as setup bait. Cradily can reliably stall foes with Toxic thanks to Recover. Storm Drain allows Cradily to pivot into Water-type attacks and prevents Scald burns from Pokemon like Toxapex. Maximum Special Defense and HP investment along with a Careful nature gives Cradily the best matchup against special attackers like Volcarona and Kyurem.

All of Cradily's teammates appreciate its ability to set up Stealth Rock, which allows sweepers like Rillaboom and Zarude to secure KOs mid- or late-game and hampers threatening Fire- and Flying-types. Rillaboom and Zarude can take care of Steel-types like Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Bisharp with their Fighting-type attacks, while Cradily can get rid of threats like Volcarona and Togekiss with Rock Blast. Choice Band Rillaboom can break past defensive cores that threaten Cradily such as Toxapex + Pelipper and Galarian Slowking + Slowbro. Rillaboom also sets Grassy Terrain for Cradily, giving it passive recovery, and is able to get rid of Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Zapdos and Mantine with Knock Off, resulting in Stealth Rock wearing down teams more effectively. Bulk Up Zarude can pressure defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Blissey, which easily wall Cradily or threaten it with Toxic, and KO Psychic- and Ghost-types like Victini and Dragapult. Ferrothorn forms a defensive core with Cradily, setting Spikes and dealing with Ice- and Fairy-types like Alolan Ninetales, Cloyster, and Tapu Lele with Gyro Ball. Its part-Steel typing gives a neutrality against Bug-type attacks and allows it to pivot into Toxic. Ferrothorn also deals with physical attackers like Excadrill for Cradily, while Cradily deals with special attackers like Nidoking in return. Amoonguss absorbs Toxic Spikes that could hinder Cradily's recovery, spreads status ailments with Spore, Stun Spore, and poison from Sludge Bomb, and switches into Fighting-type attacks from Terrakion and Keldeo that could OHKO Cradily. Celebi and Whimsicott can also deal with Fighting-types that threaten Cradily with Psychic and Moonblast, respectively. Whimsicott also helps in the Dark- and Dragon-type matchups, as it can KO Pokemon like Hydreigon, Kyurem, and Dragapult with Moonblast and provides an immunity to Dragon. Rotom-C can get rid of Flying-types like Skarmory, Celesteela, and Taunt Mandibuzz with Thunderbolt, which Cradily fails to do much against, and break through defensive cores that overpower Cradily with Nasty Plot. Choice Scarf Rotom-C can also revenge kill faster Pokemon like Garchomp and Alolan Ninetales and bring Cradily safely into the field with Volt Switch.

Latias.overview:
Dragon

Latias is an excellent revenge killer for Dragon teams thanks to its great Speed stat, good Special Attack, and Psychic typing allowing it to take care of Fighting- and Poison-types like Terrakion, Nihilego, and Galarian Weezing. Latias is a great Choice Scarf user that can revenge kill Pokemon like Dragonite after a Dragon Dance without Multiscale intact, 2HKO threats like Tapu Koko, and threaten fast Choice Scarf users like Terrakion, Nihilego, and Buzzwole. Latias also has utility options like Healing Wish and Defog, which let it fulfill a more supportive role. Levitate lets it serve as a Ground immunity and prevents it from being worn down by entry hazards. However, Latias faces competition with Latios as a revenge killer, as it has a better Special Attack and the ability to OHKO Choice Scarf Heracross and Terrakion without prior chip damage.
Latias.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Trick over Psychic or Draco Meteor can be an option to hinder special walls such as Blissey, Mantine, and Celesteela; however, it is hard to justify using it over either of these options, as losing Psychic prevents Latias from taking care of Choice Scarf Buzzwole and Heracross, while dropping Draco Meteor makes Latias unable to revenge kill boosted Dragonite and Choice Scarf Hydreigon.

Checks and Counters

Dragon

Steel-types: Latias fails to do meaningful damage to Steel-types because they resist both of its attacks. Pokemon like Excadrill and Jirachi threaten Latias with their STAB moves, while Aegislash and Bisharp OHKO it. Bulky Steel-types like Celesteela, Skarmory, and Ferrothorn wall Latias and weaken it with Toxic or Leech Seed.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types like Tapu Koko, Tapu Lele, and Tapu Fini can tank Psychic and threaten Latias with their STAB attacks.

Super Effective Attacks: Mimikyu, Spectrier, Alolan Ninetales, and Weavile are all able to tank an attack from Latias and take care of it with their super effective attacks. Dragapult can also outpace and take care of Latias if it is running Choice Scarf or after a Dragon Dance. Mamoswine is also able to take care of a weakened Latias with Ice Shard.

Specially Defensive Walls: Walls like Blissey and Mantine are able to tank both of Latias's attacks and wear it down with attacks such as Seismic Toss, Scald, and Toxic.

Status: Paralysis makes Latias unable to outpace Dragapult and Weavile, while Toxic puts it on a timer.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Dragon)
sets.description:
Draco Meteor is Latias's strongest STAB attack and allows it to revenge kill opposing Dragon-types like Hydreigon, boosted Dragonite, and Kyurem while also heavily denting physically defensive walls like Hippowdon and Mandibuzz. Psychic is a more reliable STAB option that allows Latias to take care of troublesome Fighting- and Poison-types like Terrakion, Galarian Weezing, and Choice Specs Gengar. Healing Wish can be used to fully heal threatening setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Dragapult. Levitate lets Latias come in on Ground-type attacks from Pokemon like Hippowdon and makes it immune to Spikes and Toxic Spikes. 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature allow Latias to outpace Choice Scarf users like Terrakion and Buzzwole, Speed tie with Choice Scarf Latios, and outpace naturally faster threats like Dragapult and Weavile.

All teammates appreciate Latias's Healing Wish and Defog support. Hydreigon greatly helps against troublesome Steel-types such as Aegislash, Excadrill, and Skarmory. Garchomp is useful for Stealth Rock support to secure the OHKO on Terrakion and Heracross. Garchomp can also take care of Steel-types such as Excadrill and Heatran, wall Regieleki, and take out Volcarona with Stone Edge or a boosted Scale Shot. Dragapult is very helpful in the Ghost and Psychic matchups, as it handles Gengar, Spectrier, and Tapu Lele. It can also sweep in the Dragon mirror matchup after one Dragon Dance. Kyurem is a notable partner, as it tears apart Water- and Ground-types that Latias has trouble beating, like Tapu Fini, Slowbro, Hippowdon, and Gastrodon. Dragonite is a fearsome setup sweeper that greatly helps with troublesome Fairy-, Flying-, Steel-, and Dark-types like Tapu Koko, Mantine, Heatran, and Drapion. In return, Dragonite loves Latias's ability to take care of Terrakion and Buzzwole. Dragalge is great in the Fairy and Water matchups, as it can come in on Fairy-type attacks from Tapu Fini and Tapu Koko and use Toxic Spikes to make the Fairy and Normal matchups much easier. Dracovish excels at forcing switches and tearing apart defensive cores that Latias fails to do much against, such as Blissey + Porygon2 and Celesteela + Mantine + Zapdos, with its powerful STAB attacks and coverage moves like Stone Edge. In return, Latias threatens Keldeo and Toxicroak, which give it problems. Duraludon is also an option to provide Stealth Rock and take care of troublesome Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Clefable. Kommo-o is an excellent partner that can greatly help in the Dark and Steel matchups that Latias cannot do much in.

Jirachi.overview:
Steel

Jirachi is the premier special attacker for Steel with its huge pool of coverage moves such as Psyshock, Moonblast, Thunderbolt, and Energy Ball, which allow it to improve the Poison, Dragon, Flying, Water, and Ground matchups. It also has a good Speed tier, which allows it to outspeed and OHKO threats such as Urshifu-R, Nidoking, and Hydreigon. Furthermore, its decent bulk and neutrality to Fighting allow it to take a hit in a pinch and be a good answer to Tapu Lele. However, its Special Attack is quite lackluster, as Jirachi fails to OHKO bulky Pokemon such as Kyurem, Hippowdon, and Toxapex even with Choice Specs. Because of this, Jirachi needs support from wallbreakers like Bisharp and Melmetal to remove specially defensive Pokemon, such as Galarian Slowking, and Pokemon that resist its attacks like Heatran.
Jirachi.comments:
Other Options

Steel

Aura Sphere can be used over Energy Ball to damage Ferrothorn, Magnezone, Heatran, and Tyranitar, which otherwise take negligible damage from this set; however, Steel teams can scout and punish Jirachi by switching to Aegislash, Celesteela, or Corviknight. A Calm Mind set with Moonblast, Psyshock, and Thunderbolt makes Jirachi a good wallbreaker and wincon against Poison; however, Jirachi rarely finds an opening to set up in other matchups. Trick can be used with Choice Specs to cripple specially defensive Pokemon such as Chansey, Slowking, and Galarian Slowking, but losing a coverage move is detrimental to Jirachi's effectiveness. A Choice Scarf set with Healing Wish threatens Fighting and Dragon teams better, but this set struggles to deal meaningful damage with Jirachi's mediocre Special Attack.

Checks and Counters

Steel

Specially Defensive Walls: Specially defensive Pokemon such as Chansey take negligible damage from Jirachi's attacks, and Chansey forces it out with paralysis or chip damage from Seismic Toss. Tyranitar can set up on Jirachi and threaten to sweep Steel teams unless Jirachi carries Aura Sphere.

Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon like Choice Band Weavile, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, Blacephalon, Cinderace, and Garchomp outspeed Jirachi and OHKO it with a super effective move.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Ferrothorn, Bisharp, Heatran, and Aegislash resist Jirachi's STAB moves and most of its coverage moves, and they can punish Jirachi by setting up entry hazards or by putting Steel teams in a tight spot.

Paralysis: Paralysis halves Jirachi's middling Speed, which reduces its ability to threaten most offensive teams such as Water, Flying, and Dragon teams.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Steel)
sets.description:
Psyshock allows Jirachi to significantly damage specially defensive Pokemon such as Galarian Slowking and Blissey. Moonblast deals with Dark- and Dragon-types such as Krookodile, Hydreigon, and Kommo-o. Thunder OHKOes Mantine, 2HKOes Slowking and specially defensive Celesteela, and has a high chance to paralyze the opponent's switch-in thanks to Serene Grace. Thunderbolt provides better accuracy at the cost of not being able to OHKO Mantine and the reduced probability to spread paralysis. Energy Ball helps Jirachi break Water and Ground teams by threatening Swampert, Gastrodon, and Seismitoad. A Timid nature lets Jirachi outspeed Kyurem, Urshifu-R, Hydreigon, and Nidoking.

Teammates such as Skarmory and Ferrothorn, which provide entry hazards to chip the opposing team, are excellent partners to Jirachi. Skarmory also provides a Ground immunity, checks fast physical attackers such as Terrakion, and phazes physical setup sweepers like Belly Drum Azumarill with Whirlwind. Alternatively, Corviknight can be used over Skarmory, as it allows Jirachi to come in safely with a slow U-turn while also checking Fighting-types with Brave Bird. Celesteela can also be the Ground-immune partner, as it can threaten Steel-types that wall Jirachi such as Ferrothorn with Flamethrower. Ferrothorn checks Ground- and Water-types such as Excadrill, Landorus-T, and Barraskewda, and it provides passive recovery to Jirachi in the form of Leech Seed. Heatran provides a Fire immunity and spreads Toxic to chip down defensive Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Slowbro. It can also phaze special setup sweepers such as Galarian Moltres and Hydreigon with Roar, as well as taking most special attacks aimed at Jirachi. Aegislash appreciates Jirachi removing Poison-types and aids it in the Flying and Water matchups by softening the opposing team with Toxic. Excadrill provides an Electric immunity and can outspeed and check Fire- and Steel-types such as Volcanion, Victini, and Heatran when using a Choice Scarf set. Bisharp forms a good offensive core with Jirachi, as it threatens Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Aegislash and Victini with Sucker Punch, while Jirachi helps Bisharp sweep by removing Fighting- and Dark-types such as Urshifu-R and Hydreigon. Bisharp and Excadrill also take advantage of Jirachi's wallbreaking power to clean up late-game once bulky Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss have been sufficiently chipped or removed. Melmetal punches holes in the opponent's team early-game and has enough bulk to remove troublesome Pokemon such as Cinderace, Azumarill, and Tyranitar.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Grass)
sets.description:
Roserade is an excellent Choice Scarf user due to its good Special Attack and Speed stats and the ability to set up entry hazards like Spikes and Toxic Spikes. Leaf Storm makes Roserade able to hit Water- and Ground-types like Seismitoad and Mamoswine. Sludge Bomb allows Roserade to deal with Fairy-type Pokemon like Togekiss and Grimmsnarl. Spikes is a great move to wear down teams to make it easier to clean up late-game for itself or its teammates. Toxic Spikes makes it easier to pressure teams that lack a way to get rid of them like Normal-, Fairy-, and Psychic-type teams. Having Spikes allows Ferrothorn to run Stealth Rock. Roserade should set up Spikes or Toxic Spikes against Pokemon that it can threaten such as Mamoswine, Grimmsnarl, and Togekiss. Maximum Speed EVs with a Choice Scarf and a Timid nature allow Roserade to outpace common Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Dracovish and Gardevoir. Maximum Special Attack investment ensures Roserade can hit as hard as possible.

Roserade helps with forming an entry hazard-stacking core with Ferrothorn that greatly helps chip down the opposing team. Roserade's teammates also appreciate its part-Poison typing, which allows it to absorb Toxic Spikes that would otherwise be problematic. Virizion makes a great teammate, as it can threaten Fire-types that Roserade can struggle with such as Centiskorch and Chandelure with Stone Edge. Decidueye appreciates Roserade's ability stack entry hazards, as it makes it easier for Decidueye to sweep in the Ghost- and the Psychic-type matchup. Choice Scarf Rillaboom is great to pair with Roserade due to its access to Knock Off to weaken the foe, Superpower to hit Steel-types such as Bisharp and Lucario, and U-turn to help pressure Psychic-types and bring in a teammate safely. Appletun also makes for a great teammate due to its part-Dragon-typing and great Special Defense, which allows it to come in on Fire-type attacks for Roserade while forming a good duo with Ferrothorn due to it being able to come in on Ice-type attacks. Rotom-C makes for a great partner due to being able to take on Flying-type Pokemon such as Corviknight and Mandibuzz with Nasty Plot and Thunderbolt. Whimsicott is a much-needed teammate due to its part-Fairy-typing, allowing it to help greatly in the Dragon- and Dark-type matchup. It can also help with weakening teams by using Leech Seed, which forces switches; Whimsicott and Ferrothorn appreciate Roserade's entry hazards, as it helps wear down the opposing team, and makes it easier for Roserade to clean late-game. Whimsicott can also be used for Sunny Day to make Venusaur turn into a fearful Chlorophyll sweeper with Growth and Weather Ball to help greatly with Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Bisharp.

Gastrodon.overview:
Ground

Due to Storm Drain and its solid mixed bulk, Gastrodon provides a vital Water immunity for Ground teams, allowing it to wall troublesome Pokemon like Barraskewda, Rotom-W, and Keldeo. This is very beneficial for its teammates, as Gastrodon can prevent Water-type moves from being spammed and force the opponent to play around it. Its access to Recover also gives it a huge edge over Seismitoad, since it can consistently wall the aforementioned threats without being too affected by chip damage. A neutrality to Ice allows Gastrodon to repeatedly take hits from threats to Ground teams such as Weavile, Galarian Darmanitan, and Mamoswine as well. Storm Drain's Special Attack boost can also help make Gastrodon less passive, allowing it to fire off powerful Scalds. However, replacing Seismitoad means that Gastrodon can be taken advantage of by a huge threat in Azumarill, which is able to OHKO it with Knock Off after a Belly Drum boost, proceeding to possibly sweep the rest of the entire team. Gastrodon is typically passive and can be almost completely useless against foes like Substitute Hydreigon, Substitute Kyurem, Tapu Bulu, and Zarude. Despite having solid mixed bulk, Gastrodon can be exploited by many powerful wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele, Rillaboom, and Crawdaunt due to Knock Off.
Gastrodon.comments:
Other Options

Ground

Clear Smog is an option on Gastrodon's moveset to get rid of stat boosts from Pokemon like Volcarona and Calm Mind Tapu Fini. However, replacing a move like Toxic can make it more difficult to wear down foes, forcing Gastrodon to rely on mediocre damage output. Float Stone is also an alternative item to weaken Grass Knot from foes like Alolan Raichu, Tapu Koko, and Thundurus-T. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to prevent Gastrodon from being overwhelmed by entry hazard damage.

Checks and Counters

Ground

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Rillaboom, Tapu Bulu, Ferrothorn, and Zarude are all able to force out or OHKO Gastrodon with their STAB moves. Zarude in particular is also able to remove any status condition that Gastrodon can inflict on it with Jungle Healing.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Gastrodon is pressured by many powerful wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele, Choice Specs Dragapult, Gengar, and Crawdaunt, as they are able to force massive damage on it.

Setup Sweepers: Setup sweepers such as Nasty Plot Hydreigon, Bulk Up Zarude, Calm Mind Spectrier, and Swords Dance Tapu Bulu are able to completely overwhelm Gastrodon and the rest of the team once they have set up.

Substitute Users: Substitute users such as Kyurem, Hydreigon, Spectrier, and Tapu Bulu are able to set up in front of Gastrodon, forcing it to switch out into another teammate before they get multiple boosts.

Toxic: Foes that carry Toxic such as Celesteela, Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Zapdos are able to wear down Gastrodon each turn, forcing it to use Recover more during a match and leaving it chipped so it can be KOed more easily.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ground)
sets.description:
While Earth Power is useful because of Gastrodon's higher Special Attack, Earthquake is preferred over it to break Keldeo and Dragapult's Substitute. Scald can cripple many physical attackers such as Weavile, Bisharp, Galarian Darmanitan, and Dragonite due to its decent burn chance. Toxic is able to cripple many switch-ins and foes that Gastrodon wouldn't be able to deal with otherwise such as Latios, Latias, Rotom-W, and Mantine. Recover is mandatory to heal off damage from threats like Barraskewda, Keldeo, and Kingdra, letting it consistently check them. Leftovers gives Gastrodon extra recovery in order to preserve its health better. A physically defensive spread allows Gastrodon to take hits from foes like Secret Sword Keldeo, Barraskewda, and Weavile better. Avoid getting Gastrodon too weakened by moves or status conditions like Toxic, since it will be unable to consistently wall Pokemon and may get KOed by Water-type Pokemon with other STAB moves like Urshifu-R and Kingdra.

Hippowdon forms a decent defensive core with Gastrodon, as its Sand Stream and access to Stealth Rock make it capable of wearing down foes easily. Excadrill is an excellent offensive partner that can pressure foes that give Gastrodon trouble like Latias, Zarude, Tapu Lele, Kyurem, and Tapu Bulu and function even more effectively under Hippowdon's sand. It can also remove troublesome entry hazards for Gastrodon with Rapid Spin. Mamoswine is able to revenge kill fast Dragon-, Grass-, and Flying-types that give Gastrodon trouble such as Dragapult, Hydreigon, Zarude, and Thundurus-T with Ice Shard, making it a useful wallbreaker. Nidoking is particularly useful for its ability to absorb Toxic Spikes for Gastrodon and KO problematic foes like Ferrothorn, Amoonguss, and Skarmory due to its excellent coverage and good power with Life Orb and Sheer Force. Choice Scarf Landorus-T can outspeed and revenge kill wallbreakers that Gastrodon struggles against such as Spectrier, Tapu Lele, and Gengar while removing entry hazards for it with Defog. Swords Dance Garchomp is a great wallbreaker that breaks past bulky foes such as Slowking, Ferrothorn, and Celesteela with Fire Fang while providing a useful Grass neutrality for Gastrodon. Choice Scarf Krookodile is an option to deal with Psychic- and Ghost-types that Gastrodon dislikes dealing with such as Tapu Lele, Celebi, Dragapult, and Spectrier.

sets.name: Defensive Wall (Water)
sets.description:
Thanks to its all-around good bulk, this sea slug excels as a defensive wall for Water-type teams, as a switch-in to Electric-type attacks thanks to its Ground typing, and a better option over Seismitoad on balanced teams thanks to Recover, which gives it more longevity. Earthquake allows Gastrodon to effectively damage Electric-type Pokemon like Alolan Raichu and Zeraora that otherwise threaten Water-type teams, as well as breaking Substitutes from Pokemon such as Keldeo, Primarina, Dragapult, Jirachi, and Aegislash. Scald is useful for burning physical attackers like Excadrill, Scolipede, and Hawlucha, whereas Toxic can badly poison a number of Pokemon such as an opposing Gastrodon, Galarian Corsola, and Araquanid. Recover and Leftovers allow Gastrodon to stay healthy to continue spreading status ailments and serve as a defensive pivot. However, Float Stone with maximum Special Defense investment is nice for taking on Grass Knot Heliolisk and Alolan Raichu, while Heavy-Duty Boots is valuable for avoiding entry hazard damage, particularly Toxic Spikes. Storm Drain is useful to avoid Scald burns from Pokemon such as Toxapex and Mantine, while Sticky Hold is great for Knock Off users such as Bisharp, Crawdaunt, and Weavile. Maximum HP and Defense investment allows it to better take on physical attackers such as Zeraora and Excadrill.

The entire team appreciates Gastrodon's role in absorbing Electric-type attacks; therefore, it fits on more balanced teams with Pokemon like Toxapex, Azumarill, Slowking, and Mantine. Toxapex is a glue on every Water team, as it provides utility with Knock Off, Toxic, and Toxic Spikes, and it can spread status effects just like Gastrodon. Azumarill offers a nice immunity to Grass-type attacks from Pokemon like Rillaboom and Ferrothorn and pairs well with Gastrodon, since that is its only weakness. Slowking helps with special attackers like Hatterene, Togekiss, Substitute Kyurem, and Psychic-type Pokemon that may try to use Expanding Force under Psychic Terrain against Gastrodon , while Mantine prevents special attackers like Volcarona, Hatterene, and Chandelure from setting up and sweep with Haze. In return, Gastrodon helps with physical attackers along with Toxapex thanks to their amazing Defense stats. Keldeo helps against Normal-, Ice-, and Steel-types such as Blissey, Kyurem, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn that wall Gastrodon with Secret Sword. Primarina helps with Dark-, Dragon- and Fighting-type Pokemon such as Hydreigon, Kyurem, and Keldeo thanks to its Fairy-type STAB moves, as well as beating passive defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Toxic Aegislash with Substitute and Calm Mind. Rotom-W is a nice revenge killer to Flying- and Water-type teams with Thunderbolt and offers a Ground immunity along with entry hazard removal with Defog.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Poison)
sets.description:
With its Dark typing, Skuntank manages to find itself a spot on Poison teams, being able to block Psychic-type Pokemon such as Gardevoir and Hatterene. Poison Jab does a fantastic job of handling Grass-types such as Appletun and the aforementioned Psychic-types. Sucker Punch is used to punish Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Dragapult, Jirachi, and Alolan Raichu. However, it must be used with caution in the Psychic matchup, as Jirachi's common teammate Indeedee-M blocks Skuntank from using Sucker Punch with Psychic Terrain. Defog gets rid of entry hazards while freeing Galarian Weezing from running it and removing Electric Terrain and Psychic Terrain. Protect is used to scout for moves from Choice-locked Pokemon such as Jirachi and Excadrill while also providing an additional turn of Black Sludge recovery. Aftermath is picked to punish foes that heavily depend on contact moves, such as Dracovish, Bisharp, Jirachi, and Weavile, and common U-turn users such as Dragapult and Celebi.

Galarian Weezing is a good partner with its ability Levitate, allowing it to be immune to Ground-type attacks from foes such as non-Mold Breaker Excadrill, Seismitoad, and Hippowdon. Galarian Weezing also provides Will-O-Wisp support, which can be used to cripple physically offensive Pokemon such as Mamoswine and Weavile. In return, Skuntank frees Galarian Weezing from running Defog, which creates space for coverage options such as Flamethrower and Fire Blast. Vileplume forms a solid defensive core with Skuntank with its physical bulk and Strength Sap. Moreover, with its Ground neutrality, Vileplume provides a switch-in to Mold Breaker Excadrill by always taking two unboosted attacks, and with Skuntank's Defog, Vileplume switches into Excadrill even more safely. Toxapex is a fantastic defensive pivot for many offensive Pokemon such as non-Taunt Keldeo, Dracovish, and Mimikyu. Between Toxic, Baneful Bunker, and Toxic Spikes, Toxapex comes with great potential to spread poison, which can be further exploited with Skuntank's Protect. Salazzle benefits well from Skuntank, as Skuntank can Defog entry hazards for Salazzle. This allows Salazzle to use the combination of Substitute + Toxic relatively safely and to threaten Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Aegislash with its Flamethrower. Furthermore, Salazzle can take out Choice Scarf Excadrill if it's behind Substitute. In return, Salazzle takes advantage of defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz, which Skuntank struggles against. Skuntank also helps with Toxic damage accumulation with its Protect. With its good coverage, Gengar takes out Pokemon that have the potential to exploit Skuntank, such as Ferrothorn and Corviknight. In return, Skuntank can switch into Ghost-type attacks for Gengar. Drapion can be used as a fast teammate to take out other Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Gardevoir. Furthermore, its Knock Off can remove items from foes such as Galarian Corsola, Corviknight, and Toxapex.

Bronzong.overview:
Psychic

Bronzong's Steel typing and high defenses allow it to set up Stealth Rock consistently and also act as an excellent wall for Psychic teams, soaking up Fairy- and Ice-type moves like Tapu Lele's Moonblast and Kyurem's Freeze-Dry. Levitate lets it wall Pokemon like Sand Rush Excadrill, Mamoswine, and Kyurem more easily. It stops itself from being completely passive with moves like Heavy Slam, Body Press, and Toxic. However, Bronzong faces tough competition from Jirachi, which has a higher Speed, access to U-turn to bring in teammates safely, and more utility with moves like Thunder Wave. Jirachi can even pull off an offensive Choice Scarf set, whereas Bronzong is always stuck running a defensive set.
Bronzong.comments:
Other Options

Psychic

Bronzong has no other options.

Checks and Counters

Psychic

Substitute Users: Substitute users like Aegislash and Bulk Up Landorus-T can take advantage of Bronzong's passivity and use it as setup bait.

Wallbreakers: Despite Bronzong's solid defenses, powerful wallbreakers like Choice Band Crawdaunt or Urshifu-R can OHKO or 2HKO it.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers like Taunt + Knock Off Mew shut down Bronzong easily, as it can not use its status moves or deal much damage in return.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Heavy Slam gives Bronzong some offensive presence, being able to hit Fairy-types like Tapu Bulu and Clefable. Iron Head is usually weaker than Heavy Slam, but it always breaks Kyurem's Substitute, preventing Bronzong from getting Pressure stalled. Body Press allows Bronzong to hit Steel-type Pokemon like Bisharp and Excadrill super effectively. Toxic punishes Pokemon like Mantine and Landorus-T that comfortably tank Bronzong's other moves. Toxic can also set offensive Pokemon like Dragonite and Garchomp on a timer, limiting their chances to break through Bronzong and its teammates. Levitate provides Bronzong with a Ground immunity and lets it take on foes such as Sand Rush Excadrill and Dragonite. A Colbur Berry can be used over Leftovers, letting Bronzong absorb a hit from threats like Bisharp and Weavile and punish them in return. However, forgoing Leftovers lessens oits longevity.

All of Bronzong's teammates appreciate it setting Stealth Rock, but it lets Victini in particular net KOes more easily. Bronzong can also switch in on Ground-type moves like Garchomp's Earthquake for it. Victini in return can threaten Steel-types that Bronzong struggles with, like Celesteela or Aegislash. Other offensive Pokemon like Latios and Tapu Lele greatly appreciate Stealth Rock. Tapu Lele can beat troublesome Dark-types like Crawdaunt and Hydreigon. Latios's STAB Draco Meteor and Psyshock let it tear apart cores of Pokemon like Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Drapion on Poison as well as Pelipper, Toxapex, and Swampert on Water. Galarian Slowking forms a good defensive core with Bronzong, soaking up special attacks from the likes of Tapu Koko, Aegislash, and Heatran. Slowbro also works well defensively with Bronzong. Slowbro's Water typing lets it switch into Water- and Fire-types moves from Pokemon like Barraskewda and Victini. Bronzong can then beat Pokemon like Tapu Bulu or Kyurem for Slowbro. Mew makes up for Bronzong's passivity, as it can break through defensive cores on types like Steel, Water, and Flying with the combination of Taunt + Knock Off. Calm Mind Hatterene appreciates Bronzong weakening opposing Pokemon with Stealth Rock and Toxic, giving it an easier time late-game. Nasty Plot Celebi can beat Water- and Ground-types that Bronzong is unable to dent. Bronzong helps Celebi by switching in on Poison- and Flying-type moves from Pokemon like Nihilego and Zapdos.

Garchomp.overview:
Ground

Garchomp is a powerful wallbreaker and setup sweeper thanks to Swords Dance and Scale Shot. Swords Dance allows Garchomp to destroy defensive teams, while Scale Shot allows it to gain Speed and clean through more offensive teams. It can easily set up with Swords Dance thanks to its good natural bulk. Garchomp's Speed tier allows it to excel as a cleaner and wallbreaker, taking on threats such as Urshifu-R, Kyurem, Mimikyu, Mew, and Tapu Fini. Its Dragon typing helps it tank Water- and Grass-type attacks from threats such as Rillaboom and Urshifu-R, which potentially allows Garchomp to stop a sweep. While its Speed tier and Dragon typing offer a lot, they still leave Garchomp vulnerable to common threats such as Weavile, Zarude, and Latios and compound a Ground team's natural weakness to Ice-type attacks.

Dragon

Garchomp's well rounded stat distribution, STAB coverage, and access to Stealth Rock play a pivotal role on Dragon teams and their naturally aggressive playstyle. Its Ground typing is very much appreciated against Steel- and Poison-types such as Aegislash, Melmetal, Nidoking, and Toxapex while also preventing Volt Switch pivoting from Electric-types in Rotom-W and Zapdos. Because Garchomp is used primarily for Stealth Rock support, its moveset is rather linear and simple to play around if pressured correctly.
Garchomp.comments:
Other Options

Ground

Outrage can be used over Scale Shot to break through bulky Flying-types such as Mandibuzz and Mantine with more ease on sets without Stone Edge.

Dragon

Garchomp may also sport a bulkier, defensive set equipped with a Rocky Helmet allowing it to chip physical attackers such as Melmetal, Mimikyu, and Urshifu-R through contact. However, the focus on physical bulk comes at the cost of Speed and a Focus Sash to guarantee setting Stealth Rock, while also becoming prone to setup attackers such as Spectrier.

Checks and Counters

Ground

Super Effective Attacks: Garchomp folds to faster Dragon-, Fairy-, and Ice-types with strong STAB attacks such as Dragapult, Tapu Koko, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Weavile.

Status: Garchomp does not deal with status conditions well, as being burned prevents Garchomp from being a powerful physical attacker and being Toxic poisoned puts Garchomp on a timer. Amoonguss can paralyze Garchomp with Stun Spore, preventing it from outspeeding threats such as Nidoking.

Physically Defensive Walls: Physically defensive walls such as Slowbro, Galarian Corsola, and Skarmory can take on Garchomp and threaten it with their attacks and utility options such as Scald and Whirlwind. However, these Pokemon need to be careful of Garchomp after it has used Swords Dance, as they are susceptible to its onslaught.

Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon such as Zarude, Spectrier, and Choice Scarf Landorus-T can bring Garchomp down with their STAB attacks; however, if they fail to KO Garchomp, they need to be wary of its attacks.

Phazers: Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Avalugg, and Swampert can remove Garchomp's boosts with Whirlwind or Roar and force it out.

Dragon

Physically Defensive Walls: Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Amoonguss, and Slowbro can easily wall Garchomp without a Swords Dance boost. Additionally, Corviknight and Celesteela are particularly difficult for Garchomp to deal with, given they are part-Flying-type and have the ability to recover any damage taken.

Burns: Although its purpose is to be a suicide lead, burns severely hinder Garchomp's damage output and whittle away at its health.

Revenge Killers and Faster Threats: Pokemon such as Weavile, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Tapu Koko can easily outpace Garchomp and take it out with their STAB attacks.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Ground)
sets.description:
Swords Dance allows Garchomp to become a dangerous wallbreaker by letting it OHKO Pokemon such as Tapu Fini with Earthquake and Kyurem with Scale Shot and beating walls such as Amoonguss and Celesteela with more ease. Scale Shot boosts Garchomp's Speed, allowing it to revenge kill faster threats such as Tapu Koko, but it drops Garchomp's Defense and makes it vulnerable to priority attacks such as Rillaboom's Grassy Glide and Bisharp's Sucker Punch. Stone Edge targets Flying-types such as Zapdos, Galarian Moltres, Mantine, and Mandibuzz. Fire Fang hits Grass- and Steel-types such as Tapu Bulu, Ferrothorn, and Celesteela; the latter two are not phased by Garchomp's other attacks. Life Orb allows Garchomp to be a stronger wallbreaker and gives it crucial rolls such as OHKOing bulky Tapu Fini with Swords Dance-boosted Earthquake. Alternatively, Lum Berry can be used to give Garchomp a safer chance to set up against status users such as Blissey, Amoonguss, and Toxapex. Rough Skin allows Garchomp to better handle physical threats such as Urshifu-R.

Hippowdon provides residual damage chip on foes such as Tapu Fini and Tapu Bulu with Stealth Rock and sand and makes it easier for Garchomp to break through them. Excadrill benefits from Hippowdon's sand thanks to Sand Rush and can aid Garchomp by revenge killing Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-types such as Alolan Ninetales and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and clearing entry hazards. Garchomp and Excadrill also benefit from each other breaking down shared checks such as Slowbro and Mandibuzz, allowing the other an easier time sweeping. Gastrodon and Seismitoad offer Garchomp a Water immunity. Gastrodon is the more sustainable option, as it provides a more consistent switch-in to threats such as Barraskewda due to it having reliable recovery, while Seismitoad can deal with threats like Belly Drum Azumarill. Choice Scarf Landorus-T can revenge kill threats such as Dragapult and Tapu Koko, while Gravity Landorus-T allows both itself and Garchomp to check Celesteela, Skarmory, and Corviknight without relying on Fire Fang. Mamoswine takes on Flying-, Dragon-, and Grass-types such as Landorus-T, Latios, and Amoonguss with its powerful Ice-type attacks while also being able to revenge kill Pokemon such as Dragapult for Garchomp. Additionally, Mamoswine can remove items such as Slowbro's Heavy-Duty Boots and Tapu Lele's Choice Scarf, opening up avenues Garchomp to beat them. Nidoking can help Garchomp take on the Steel and Flying matchups, hitting all Steel-types with Earth Power + Flamethrower and all Flying-types with BoltBeam coverage, and take pressure off it. Nidoking can break through Pokemon such as Celesteela, Corviknight, and Skarmory for Garchomp; in return, Garchomp can break past special walls such as Blissey. Choice Scarf Krookodile helps in the Ghost and Psychic matchups, allowing Garchomp to become more threatening by removing faster threats such as Spectrier, Dragapult, Latias, and Alakazam.

sets.name: Stealth Rock (Dragon)
sets.description:
This set has Garchomp utilizing its solid Speed stat to set Stealth Rock as fast as possible while damaging foes as much as possible before it gets knocked out. Earthquake and Stone Edge are solid moves for it to use, as the former is a high-powered Ground-type STAB move namely hitting Steel-types like Jirachi and Heatran, while the latter is coverage against Flying-types like Galarian Moltres and Zapdos. Swords Dance enhances its early-game breaking power, though Toxic is also usable to whittle away at physically defensive Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Rotom-W, and Slowbro. Maximum Speed and a Jolly nature ensure that Garchomp is as fast as possible, allowing it to outpace threats such as Zapdos and Tapu Lele.

Garchomp's set is meant to enable other Dragon-types to decimate its foes through setup, revenge killing, and sheer power, to which Dragon teams has a large arsenal of teammates to work with. That being said, Dragon-types such as Dragapult, Dragonite, Hydreigon, and Latios offer their insane offensive coverage, setup options, and overall breaking power to make the most of the residual damage Garchomp provides, whether it be through entry hazard damage or Rough Skin contact. Dragapult especially complements Garchomp's functions, as its great offensive typing, blistering Speed, and set versatility pressure a vast majority of the metagame and keep its foes on their heels. Latias is an ideal teammate for it given its affinity to remove entry hazards for Dragon team while also providing Healing Wish support to restore its health and status if need be. Kyurem is useful to Pressure stall many defensive and utility-based foes such as Blissey and Mew while also utilizing Freeze-Dry to counteract difficult Water-types in Gastrodon and Tapu Fini.

sets.name: Nasty Plot (Steel)
sets.description:
Lucario serves as the premier special setup sweeper for Steel teams able to revenge kill threats with its priority Vacuum Wave. Nasty Plot makes Lucario a threatening sweeper; after one boost Lucario can OHKO Hydreigon with Vacuum Wave. Vacuum Wave also provides a form of priority that can be used to check faster threats such as Galarian Darmanitan and Heliolisk. At +2 Lucario can OHKO Hydreigon with Vacuum Wave. Dark Pulse is an option that allows Lucario to take on Aegislash, which can otherwise use Lucario as setup fodder. Life Orb allows Lucario to increase its damage output. Its EV spread and a Modest nature allow it to hit as fast and hard as possible. Lucario prefers to run a Modest nature to boost the power of its Vacuum Wave. Lucario should set up on Pokemon like Mandibuzz and Sableye that will try to cripple it with Foul Play and Will-O-Wisp, respectively. Since Lucario is a setup sweeper, try to set it up on Pokemon it can force out or Pokemon that can't touch it such as Galarian Corsola.

All of its teammates appreciate its ability to take on Dark- and Steel-type Pokemon, as well as being able to revenge kill faster threats such as Excadrill with priority Vacuum Wave. Duraludon and Ferrothorn are Steel teams' main entry hazard setters and support Lucario by making its sweep easier. Corviknight can provide Lucario with a Ground-type immunity and can take on Ghost-type Pokemon for Lucario if it decides to not run Dark Pulse with Bulk Up + Power Trip. Aegislash, Excadrill, Durant, and Bisharp all appreciate its ability to help them break past physical walls; in return, they can take on Pokemon that Lucario struggles with such as Dragapult. Additionally, Bisharp and Aegislash can also help Lucario check faster threats with their priority moves in Sucker Punch and Shadow Sneak, respectively. Excadrill also can clear entry hazards for Lucario with Rapid Spin and take on Electric-type Pokemon such as Dracozolt.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fighting)
sets.description:
Lucario is a great physical attacker due to having good Attack, Speed, and priority in Bullet Punch that helps greatly with the Fairy-type matchups. Bullet Punch is a great priority move that can help greatly in the Fairy- and Ice-type matchup, being able to hit Gardevoir, Ribombee, Mimikyu and Mamoswine. Meteor Mash is to help net KOs against slower Fairy-type Pokemon such as Togekiss and Clefable. Extreme Speed is used to be able to hit Pokemon like Salazzle and Dracovish. Lucario should try to set up on a predicted switch, on a passive Pokemon, or on a Pokemon it threatens out. Running an Adamant nature allows Lucario to take care of most Fairy-types after one Swords Dance, while running a Jolly nature with maximum Speed EVs allows Lucario to outpace Togekiss and Kommo-o.

All Fighting-type Pokemon love Lucario for its Steel typing allowing it to threaten Fairy-types like Gardevoir and Togekiss. Cobalion is a much needed teammate to set down Stealth Rock, cripple Pokemon like Choice Scarf Gardevoir with Thunder Wave, and Taunt opposing leads such as Galarian Corsola. Terrakion is a great Choice Scarf user due to it outpacing Choice Scarf Excadrill and Gardevoir and being able to take on Fire-types like Charizard and Chandelure. Keldeo is also very helpful for Lucario due to it taking down Ground- and Fire-type Pokemon like Hippowdon, Excadrill, and Charizard while also stopping Toxapex using Recover, Haze or Toxic Spikes thanks to Taunt. Scrafty is needed, as it provides a useful Psychic immunity to the team, uses its ability Shed Skin to soak status for its teammates, which helps Lucario with not being burned, and takes on Ghost-type Pokemon such as Aegislash and Sableye for the team. Kommo-o is a great teammate for Lucario due to its Dragon typing, allowing it to threaten Dragon-types such as Dracozolt. Toxicroak forms a core with Lucario that can break through Fairy-types help greatly in the matchup thanks to its Poison typing.

Hippowdon.overview:
Ground

Hippowdon is an invaluable teammate on sand-based Ground teams thanks to its ability to automatically set sand, notably supporting a dangerous teammate in Excadrill. On top of that, its good physical bulk and useful utility options in Stealth Rock, Slack Off, and Whirlwind make it a good check to physical attackers like Garchomp, Dragapult, and Cinderace. However, Hippowdon's weaknesses to Water, Grass, and Ice leave it susceptible to attackers like Barraskewda, Rillaboom, and Kyurem. It's also overwhelmed by powerful special attackers like Tapu Lele, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Hydreigon due to its average Special Defense. Due to its reliance on Earthquake in order to deal damage, Hippowdon is typically passive and taken advantage of Taunt users like Zarude and Tapu Fini while being unable to damage Flying-types like Landorus-T, Corviknight, and Celesteela.
Hippowdon.comments:
Other Options

Ground

Yawn can be used over Whirlwind to force out threats such as Celesteela, Corviknight, and Zapdos that can switch in with impunity while still helping against setup sweepers like Dragonite and Mimikyu. Toxic is another option over Whirlwind, punishing non-Poison-immune walls such as Mantine, Swampert, and Mandibuzz much more effectively; however, the utility from Whirlwind is generally more appreciated.

Checks and Counters

Ground

Special Attackers: Because of Hippowdon's average special bulk, it is vulnerable to powerful special wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele, Spectrier, and Choice Specs Dragapult.

Stallbreakers: Stallbreakers such as Zarude, Calm Mind + Taunt Tapu Fini, and Taunt Mew can easily shut down Hippowdon by forcing it to use Earthquake while preventing it from recovering with Slack Off or phazing setup attempts with Whirlwind.

Status: Toxic cripples Hippowdon by putting it on a timer, leaving it unable to check threats more consistently. Burn negates Leftovers recovery and significantly reduces the power of Earthquake, making Hippowdon more passive against foes like Scizor and Garchomp.

sets.name: Sand Setter
sets.description:
Earthquake prevents Hippowdon from being completely passive, wearing down physical attackers such as Garchomp, Scizor, and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Slack Off allows it to wall threats like Cinderace more consistently and set sand more times throughout a match. Whirlwind phazes threatening setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Garchomp, and Mimikyu while being able to wear down foes in conjunction with sand and Stealth Rock damage. Forgoing Leftovers will slightly reduce Hippowdon's longevity, but Eject Button can be used over it to safely pivot out into a teammate like Excadrill once sand has been set up, allowing it to sweep more easily. Maximum HP investment with an Impish nature allows Hippowdon to take on threats like Bisharp, Excadrill, and Dragon Dance Dragapult more easily. 128 Special Defense EVs let it survive Choice Specs Latios's Draco Meteor and Tapu Koko's Grass Knot at full health. Hippowdon should be preserved in matchups like Fairy and Ice to set sand so that a teammate like Excadrill can sweep.

Excadrill is a mandatory teammate for Hippowdon, as it greatly benefits from the sand that it sets thanks to Sand Rush. It can outspeed threats like Choice Scarf Galarian Darmanitan, Choice Scarf Weavile, and Tapu Lele under sand, remove troublesome entry hazards with Rapid Spin, and deal with threatening Ice-, Psychic-, and Fairy-types such as Kyurem, Latias, and Tapu Bulu. Gastrodon and Seismitoad both provide a Water immunity; Gastrodon's Recover lets it consistently check threats like Weavile and Barraskewda, while Seismitoad is useful to specifically check Azumarill. Nidoking can deal with troublesome Grass- and Flying-types for Hippowdon such as Ferrothorn, Tapu Bulu, Celesteela, and Mantine, as well as Steel teams, thanks to its amazing coverage. Additionally, it absorbs Toxic Spikes due to its part-Poison typing. Mamoswine is a fearsome wallbreaker that is especially useful in the Flying and Dragon matchups, as it deals with threats like Mandibuzz, Hydreigon, and Latias thanks to its Ice Shard. Choice Scarf Krookodile is used to revenge kill Ghost- and Psychic-types that threaten Hippowdon such as Spectrier, Tapu Lele, and Choice Specs Dragapult.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Dark)
sets.description:
Thanks to its part-Poison typing and access to Toxic Spikes, Drapion serves as a Choice Scarf user for Dark-type teams with the capability of handling Fairy-types. With the Speed boost, Drapion can remove Choice Scarf from Dracovish and Dracozolt with Knock Off, thus granting Dark-type teams a sufficient counterplay, and can safely break the Disguise of Mimikyu. Poison Jab is used to handle Fairy-types such as Hatterene and Gardevoir. Toxic can be used to cripple bulky Pokemon on the switch, such as Hippowdon, and Toxic Spikes helps Dark against some types, such as Fairy and Dragon.
